SAP’s North Star Architecture  Abstract  
This document explains the principles of the North Star Architecture  and put s it into the context of 
the intelligent suite and the Business Technology Platform . It starts with a summary of what  you 
must  know about the North Star Architecture  – its purpose, timelines, resulting obligations, etc . If 
you do  not have time, you should at least read this  summary . 
The rest of the document explains in more detail, why we need a North  Star Architecture , the 
process es to reach  cross -product architecture decisions , and which  engi neering principles we are  
pursuing. We  also explain  the strategy of a common platform  and introduc e the building blocks of 
the Business Technology Platform  from an architectural  standpoint . 
Starting on page 32, we give a  detailed description of the current topic areas  that are discussed in 
the North Star Architecture working groups.  You can use these as a reference for the current state of 
discussion on major cross -product architecture topics.

SAP’s North Star Architecture  Summarized Overview – What you Need to  Know  
SAP’s Product Strategy is to establish SAP as the leading provider of true cloud enterprise solutions. 
We aspire to deliver an intelligent suit e1, an integrated  set of products that provides a consistent 
experience with common high -value Suite Qualities . In this document,  the intelligent suite is used to 
refer to the entirety  of SAP’s cloud SaaS offering  plus S/4HANA  on-premise , as in our product vision ; 
all appl ications are part of the suite and follow the principles of the North Star Architecture.  The 
intelligent suite ’s product vision commits and brings together all major SAP product areas to a 
collaborative effort to build applications and services , along a sh ared understanding , using a single 
platform  as the technical foundation of our cloud offerings.  
The N orth Star Architecture  in a Nutshell  
To accomplish our goal, we introduce an architectural "North Star": a set of sound engineering 
principles and guidance for building modern and integrated cloud enterprise software. The North 
Star Architecture provides an architectural target state for a broad number of engineering topics, 
targeting  the entire intelligent suite , all of SAP’s cloud  applications ’ architectures , as well as  the 
underlying single platform, called the Business Technology Platform  (BTP) . Figure 1 indicates the 
scope of the North Star Architecture and how it covers the intelligent suite as a whole, including 
applications and BTP.  
To describe a path towards the desired target state, it provides  architectural rules, guardrails, 
conventions , and guida nce. They  are defined through a cross-product architecture  working model , 
involving working groups of experts from all major SAP product areas , and are rolled out via 
Technology Guidelines  (TGs) . We continuously iterate, improve  the TGs , add new decisions  to them , 
and ensure that development can execute with confidence. We should achieve the target

SAP’s North Star Architecture  architecture by 2023 , and we  provide guidance that is already applicable today  to start the journey 
towards the North Star.  
Developers  apply the guidance to create new greenfield solutions and to evolve existing ones to the 
cloud while integrating them in to the intelligent suite . We seek a soft migration and iterative 
convergence to the target state; not a small challenge, given the existing user base, amount of 
managed data , and functional breadth in our fractured landscape. The rewards are a reduced system 
fragmentation, improved reliability, higher development velocity , and – most importantly  – a 
superior user experience.  
The guidance  (mostly marked by the icon on the left)  provided herein principally targets our 
own employees  and is considered INTERNAL - but is just as relevant to developers in our 
partner and customer ecosystem.  The content will be conveyed to them with an appropriate 
communication strateg y over time.  
SAP’s Business Technology Platform  
The Business Technology Platform (BTP) is the foundation 
structure  of the North Star Architecture. Its definition is a 
natural evolution of  the Cloud Platform Strategy of 2019 .  
Develope rs of applications and service providers  build on the 
BTP as the single, unifying platform that provides the 
foundation of our cloud offerings to build, integrate , and 
extend. The transition from autonomous application stacks to 
the BTP is a major strategi c shift . Over time, all capabilities in 
the intelligent suite  will be consumable through this common platform, especially those that provide 
a benefit across products.  
To facilitate this, the BTP consists from an architectural perspective of three  main parts : application 
plane, data plane  and foundational plane .  
From an architectural perspective t he application plane  provide s the client -facing entry -point to the 
intelligent suite . The focus here is to achi eve a harmonized  approach  to exposing the  business -
domain model , business domain services , and flexible business process es. Consistent  building blocks 
like user interface components , experience components (e.g.,  one-inbox ), a central entry point , a 
marketplace, SAP Graph and the underlying SAP One Domain Model all lead to a consistent user 
experience for a perceived homogenous product suite.  By being a centralized entry point, it also 
allows us to rethink our customer experience.  This plane  also enab les a standardized approach to 
customization and extension.  
From an architectural perspective t he data plane  provides semantic and consistent access to all 
enterprise data across SAP systems/services , manifesting core principles of enterprise data 
manageme nt in the cloud . It combines SAP’s  entire  portfolio of data -related Cloud services into a 
single logical plane to provide, integrate, derive, and analyze data to enhance the value for the 
customer.  It contains  data management solutions, like managed SAP HANA services, SAP Analytics, 
Data Intelligence, Master Data Integration, and more.  Data management technologies will mainly be 
consumed by applications as managed services in the future; therefore,  the data plane implements 
cloud qualities including elast icity, high availability, and cost efficiency to achieve the needed 
acceptance by applications.  
From an architectural perspective t he foundational plane  establishes a common baseline of reusable 
services , as well as an open approach to grow an “organic eco system” of services . This plane  includes 
the Kernel Services  (identity -service, audit log, event bus, subscription management, data privacy,

SAP’s North Star Architecture  and more), but also a broad spectrum of technical re -use services that drive synergies across the 
platform.  The core of the foundational plane  is a service management infrastructure, combined with  
a secure mesh for cross -service trusted communication. We strive for uniformity of the services with 
guardrails  on API -based and event -based integration, but also UI integration. We expect service 
providers to offer cloud -native SLAs for their service, meaning committing to both measurable KPIs 
as well as a superior consumption experience (time -to-value) and succes sfully fulfilled quality criteria 
(conformance to product standards, security, etc.).  
Development  services  support the developer from SAP and its ecosystem. Providing solutions for 
developers who range from professional " cloud native" developers, to casual or "citizen" developers, 
this includes programming paradigms ( ABAP in the cloud , CAP, RAP, etc. ), SDKs , and a variety of 
development tools.  
Developers must target high availability, elasticity and scalability, pay -per-use consumption  and trial, 
operability of services, etc. To avoid reinventing the wheel, best -practices and patterns embodied in 
the development services  result in higher development productivity , while aiming to remain  flexible 
to break out where needed, e.g. to experiment and innovate.  
We also provide three distinct yet open programming model layers  that define tool sets for different 
developer personas based on different needs and skills: a flexible  cloud  native model  with full 
control, a high -level coding model  that offers conveniences for common business application 
development tasks  and a low/no -code model for citizen developer that features  graphical extension, 
configuration and customization  capabilities . These layers complement each other and allow the 
comb ination of tools, such as the progression from “low code to pro code”.  
Technology Guidelines  and Suite Qualities  
Cross -product architecture working groups cover the many  North Star Architecture topics and  
develop peer -reviewed documents that describe the architecture at a detailed level.  These are then 
further refined until they can be operationalized by means of Technology Guidelines  (TGs) . TGs are 
the concrete  basis for the prioritization of requirements , as well as the commitment to the execution 
and release dates by all LoBs. TGs are mandatory  for all products  in SAP ’s intelligent suite.  
TG adoption is communicated to customers by means of Suite Qualities . They describe what  (and 
when ) we are going to deliver , whereas TGs focus on how  we achieve this internally. Suite Qualities 
and the underlying TGs are defined in waves. The first wave of Suite Qualities was publicly 
announced in the paper “ Intelligent Enterprises Are Integrated Enterprises ” in February 2020  
(updated in July) , after the Technology Guidelines had already been  made  available for a whil e and 
had reached a mature state . In July, customers also received updates on the integration roadmap by 
Christian Klein  (CEO) “Integration Makes All the Difference: An Update to Our Integration Road Map 
in the Cloud ” and Jürgen Müller (CTO) “Progress Report and Updates to SAP’s Integration Road Map 
in the Cloud ”.

SAP’s North Star Architecture  Guidance  Overview  
This paper dives deeply  into many of the architectural topics – comprising the BTP and the various 
cross -topics like end-to-end extensibility, operational excellence , and life cycle management . We 
encourage the reader to spend some time b ecoming familiar with these topics . In this abstract , we 
provide a short summary of the main points discussed and the consequent practical guidance2. 
Engineering Principl es 
The trend that enabled agile innovation at web scale is the move from monolithic to microservices 
architectures.  However, as a microservices architecture trades one set of problems for another , SAP 
shall follow this approach only where it is beneficial . Managing a large distributed system of 
hundreds or thousands of microservices , the communication between them and securing them are 
non-trivial problems.  Engineering principles are important for SAP and its customers a s they align  at 
a fundamen tal level how  software engineering is conducted to produce  enterprise -grade  services in 
an organizationally scalable and reproducible fashion at constantly high quality.

Engineering Principl es 
The trend that enabled agile innovation at web scale is the move from monolithic to microservices 
architectures.  However, as a microservices architecture trades one set of problems for another , SAP 
shall follow this approach only where it is beneficial . Managing a large distributed system of 
hundreds or thousands of microservices , the communication between them and securing them are 
non-trivial problems.  Engineering principles are important for SAP and its customers a s they align  at 
a fundamen tal level how  software engineering is conducted to produce  enterprise -grade  services in 
an organizationally scalable and reproducible fashion at constantly high quality.   
Engineering excellence for a web -scale business includes a number of principles  to de fine a 
developer environment that yields flexibility, productivity , and predictability , such as:  
• “You build it, you run it”. DevOps and SRE (Site Reliability Engineering) must be  practiced 
systematically, using CI/CD, observability and automation . 
• Microser vices, APIs, and asynchronous messaging are key to achieve loose coupling . 
• Security is ensured by defense in depth, identity and access management, principles of least 
privilege, and encryption of data at rest and in motion . 
• The use of SAP design ( TAM  and UML ) and product standards . 
A highly desirable suite experience that is perceived on the outside as a homogeneous system is 
founded internally on a set of loosely coupled applications, services and technology components that 
follow common rules, guardrails, conventions and best practices to reduce the entropy and 
fragmentation in our portfolio. Our intent is to provid e guidance and define rules as much as 
possible on a “macro level” that governs the interaction of applications and services. On the “micro 
level” – the internals of the services – we aim to provide blueprints and guidance on best  practices to 
build compli ant services, while retaining a healthy level of  flexibility within each service.  
Further engineering principles  that we introduce  are cloud native development,  service  orientation 
(consuming and providing services based on API enablement and a service man agement foundation), 
an event -driven architecture  (loosely coupl ing individual services ), and the SAP One Domain Model, 
which harmonizes key domain entities in the intelligent suite  to facilitate integration and analytics 
use cases.  
Runtime Environments , Containers , and Kubernetes  
Software execution environments are fundamental components that have an impact on many non -
functional aspects of software development and delivery. SAP’s , our customers’ and partners’ 
developers expect to have a choice of environments  that address different  project needs . We must 
ensure that all environments provide equal access to platform capabilities  and support multiple  
infrastructure s. 
Containers and Kubernetes workload management technologies are the new lingua franca of cloud 
operating systems – technologies that help today’s industry bridge gaps between diverse execution 
environments.

SAP’s North Star Architecture   The guidance is that a Kubernet es-based approach is now the default option for building 
new platforms, services, and applications. Gardener from SAP is the default approach for 
Kubernetes cluster management. During the North Star timeframe, most of our workloads 
adopt this technology.  
Built on top of this foundation, managed runtimes will be provided that make it easy to adopt 
opinionated development approaches. These are the Cloud Foundry runtime and the ABAP runtime 
to cater to our established developer base. In addition, we provide an opinionated “open build -on” 
approach that caters to cloud native developers who want to develop close to the technical 
foundation. A key enabler is that all services on the platform must be consumable from all these 
runtime environments. We are going to  adopt a service mesh to provide secure and standardized 
inter -service connectivity, while also enabling the extraction of key technical functionalities (like 
logging or traffic rules) from the microservices using a side -car approach.  
Application and Service Development  
Customers and partners do not only expect SAP to deliver a platform of technology services, but also 
best -practice patterns, blueprints , and frameworks that enable them to effectively utilize these 
technologies to achieve the desired business outcomes.  It is expected that customers can focus 
mainly on writing their business logic  and otherwise rely on what SAP determines to be best  
practices.  Cloud native is the dominant development paradigm, w ith full support for Java/Spring, 
Node.js, and ABAP as primary languages for SAP. The use of modern CI/CD is mandatory, using 
shared source repositories (inner source) and open source across SAP, to encourage reuse. 
Development frameworks like CAP support business developers in using technologies like OData, 
Fiori, and SAP HANA.  
Infrastructure and Multi -Cloud Strategy  
Customers and partners frequently have an existing cloud provider strategy and existing landscapes , 
which results in requirements towards SAP solutions to be more flexible about cloud provider choice 
than our competitors. Also, with the breadth of  markets and  geographies  covered  by SAP solutions , 
one provid er is often not sufficient to reach the necessary  coverage . As we need to account for these 
diverse needs in an enterprise context, we outline a holistic approach to multi -cloud that covers 
public cloud providers, SAP infrastructure , and custome rs’ private  clouds. SAP's multi -cloud strategy 
is one of no -compete on commodity infrastructure services, leveraging hyperscalers, while providing  
choice and flexibility  – both for the deployment of our own solutions  and for those of our ecosystem . 
We must account for the many legal and regulatory requirements around data locality.  
While applications are free to use a strategy of choice, based on business considerations, kernel 
services must be available in the regional hubs in which we  operate our business . Hyperscaler 
services can be used in production, as long as the team assesses  the risks of vendor lock -in and  
complies with North Star guidance , SAP product standards , applicable laws , etc. A list of compliant 
hyperscaler services will be made available soon.  
SAP’s data centers and network infrastructure remain strategic assets, and we will  modernize and 
harmonize o ur own IaaS stacks based on VMWare (GCS “PlusOne”) , as well as bare metal using 
Kubernetes. In addition, we propose a set of backbone and edge services that complement our 
infrastructure to more effectively and securely serve global clients.

SAP’s North Star Architecture  Data Management and Analytics  
Data storage and analytics are  a key to success for any business. Customers expect that SAP’s 
applications and data technology are closely interlocked  and pre -integrated , resulting in a faster 
“time to value” when using SAP technology to analyze SAP  application  data. Delivering value from 
the data in our intelligent suit e is a major proposition that needs to be enabled by Data Lake and 
Data Mesh approaches. Managed data services, combined with rich and aligned semantic data 
models shared across applications, comprise the “Data Plane”. The Data Plane constitutes an end -to-
end solution to managed services for data processing for business applications . We address the 
needs of customers and partners, and those of our own product teams . The “Data Plane” , therefore , 
includes managed databases (HANA Cloud Services), data integrat ion and data movement, AI/ML 
and analytical capabilities  - all deeply integrated in a common “suite data experience”. A common 
semantic data model based on the SAP One Domain Model is the key enabler in the Data Plane to 
achieve a homogeneous view on our h eterogeneous data sources.   
 HANA and SAP Analytics Cloud are mandatory for structured business data and embedded 
analytics respectively.  
Integrated Intellige nt Suite  Foundations  
The topic of integration focuses on the challenges SAP faces in forming a well -integrated suite  out of 
our different business applications by creating integrated consistency across all of them . For several 
years, customers have demanded that SAP provides a reasonable level of “out of the box” 
integration  and reduce the efforts for implementation and operation . SAP benefits strategically, as 
deep integration make s it a clear choice for  a custome r to expand SAP’s suite with new capabilities , 
instead of choosing competitor “best -of-breed” solutions . 
Integration has been one of the most intensive activities, which is reflected in the number of TGs 
that have been published until now (e.g. TG02 , TG03 , TG04 , TG27 , TG29 , TG31 , TG39 ) and the kernel 
service activities around integration.  
• Kernel Services include the Identity Services, Master Data Integration ( based on SAP One Domain 
Model) and the concept of (operational) zones.  Othe r topics of intense interest are service 
discovery and business configuration .

SAP’s North Star Architecture  Operation al Excellence  and Lifecycle Management  (LM)  
Product standards (operations and support, software lifecycle) and Technology Guidelines already 
address LM aspects of our cloud native solutions. Still, there is a lot more to do to reduce TCO 
through more automated provisioning and integration , subscript ion management and system 
landscape registration , and information services. We seek a unified approach across LoBs, managing 
heterogenous and distributed applications , as one integrated suite from an operations perspective.  
Customers and partners benefit f rom a more streamlined experience , faster time to value, increased 
agility , and reduced operational overhead  in the day -to-day interactions with SAP . 
End-to-end Extensibility  
The end -to-end extensibility experience across the full intelligent suite plays a significant role in the 
implementation experience of SAP customers. Extensibility touches the entire ecosystem.  Today this 
topic is handled differently across our different applications , requiring  huge learning curves  across 
business processes . Partners expect us to deliver an end -to-end extensibility approach that allows 
them to build and sell extension solutions for the intelligent suite, and they expect SAP to no t only 
provide an appropriate technical framework, but also the commercial side (e.g. marketplace) in a 
similar fashion to our competitor s’ offerings . 
We must  consolidate the end -to-end extensibility experience across the intelligent suite, 
orchestrating u nder the hood all related technical artifacts across the different technology stacks 
and solutions. We encourage side-by-side extensibility, in addition to harmonizing the traditional in -
app extensibility. For example, TG12  and the  Field Extension Hub  will support  orchestrating custom 
fields across multiple different products. Similarly - SAP Graph introduces a suite -wide unified and 
extensible API entry  point exposing  the SAP One Domain Model, the result of the ongoing DMA 
initiative .  
We will gradually expand this towards other technical artifacts, orchestrated by a Central 
Management Plane, with the ambition to include 3rd party systems. Based on this foundation, w e will 
focus on growing our ISV partner ecosystem. It must become easy for partners to get involved, 
register, and certify their extension scenarios. Customers must be able to discover, try, and consume 
partner -provid ed extension scenarios via a seamless in-app self -service consumption experience. We 
will establish and monitor experience KPIs for both how partners interact with SAP, as well as how 
customers consume partner extension scenarios in their SAP systems.  
Security and Identity Management  
Our customers have high expectations for the platform harmonization of security, data protection, 
legal and regulatory compliance, and integration. SAP’s evolutionary approach towards cloud 
computing and our acquisitions have compounded our challenges.  
Modern , central  authentication and authori zation , encryption  at rest and in transit, and central ized 
policy con figurations are all becoming mandatory for intelligent suite applications. Authorization 
claims, not merely identities , should be used for access control decisions. Several important TGs 
have been published in this area ( “TG02  – Identity Authentication and SSO ” and  “TG16  - Identity 
Provisioning  and Lifecycle Management ” are two examples ). The audit log Kernel Service  is used to 
standardize how audit logs are stored and further distributed.  
User Experience  
Our customers do not only expect that SAP covers  their business requirements, but also an end user 
experience that is desirable and state -of-the-art. High quality user  experience drives adopti on, 
increases productivity, reduces training efforts, and reflects positively on SAP’s brand.  We take an  
architectural approach to attain a harmonized experience based on the Fiori Design with a central 
©2020 SAP SE – Internal    11 
  
 
SAP’s North Star Architecture  user -facing entry point. This composable experience c ombines elements from multiple services and 
applications, using functionality building blocks for both business domain (e.g. , a cost center display 
card) and the experience domain ( e.g., a task inbox widget). Such micro frontend components target 
multiple device types , using open standards and open web technologies. The composition is to occur 
in a central user -facing entry -point of the BTP. A best practice set of technologies will be provided to 
internal developers as an SDK ( Software Development Kit ) for service/application developers and an 
CDK ( Component Development Kit) for component developers.

SAP’s North Star Architecture  Introduction  
Technology is the foundation of SAP. Combined with our business applications, processes , and 
ingrained Suite Qualities, our technology is what customers rely on to be successful. Customers need 
harmonized and highly integrated products to remain agile and react to rapidly changing 
requirements. This has never been more critical and is the reason why we pursue our Intelligent 
Enterprise  program, the largest engineering project that we currently run at SAP.  
SAP uses the term "Intelligent Enterprise" to describe those of our customers who "run best with 
SAP".  In a ground -breaking manifest  on LinkedIn, SAP's CEO, Christian Klein , publicly committed to 
support " every customer to become an intelligent enterprise ". The topic  “Intelligent Enterprise ” was 
the main theme of SAPPHIRE NOW 2020.  
The means to fulfill  this commitment  is to build an integrated  set of products, delivered as an 
intelligent suite  with common high -value

SAP uses the term "Intelligent Enterprise" to describe those of our customers who "run best with 
SAP".  In a ground -breaking manifest  on LinkedIn, SAP's CEO, Christian Klein , publicly committed to 
support " every customer to become an intelligent enterprise ". The topic  “Intelligent Enterprise ” was 
the main theme of SAPPHIRE NOW 2020.  
The means to fulfill  this commitment  is to build an integrated  set of products, delivered as an 
intelligent suite  with common high -value Suite Qualities . Our goal is to integrate our LoB 
applications in an efficient wa y, along defined end -to-end business processes. This includes a 
seamless user experience, aligned domain models, embedded cross -product analytics , and one 
workflow inbox. Simplification  – mainly the consolidation of our technology stacks across the 
intelli gent suite , Industry Clouds , and the Business Technology Platform  – are an important effort to 
achieve the Suite Qualities our customers demand  and to become more efficient internally.  
However, the only way to successfully  deliver an intelligent suite , spanning most of our products, is 
to have a common engineering foundation across all our teams. This common engineering 
foundation is what we call SAP’s North Star Architecture . Driven by a collaborative community of 
SAP's most senior architects, it align s SAP's entire engineering community around a shared  high -level 
architecture stack and common  engineering principles, technologies , and practices across all of SAP.  
The North Star Architecture  vision is the foundation that provides teams across SAP with a  long -term 
stable desired target picture of the future  architecture of the intelligent suite. From this vision , we 
can derive guidance on how to build tools, applications, and services.  
Collaborating across the entire SAP team  enables us to create  a bette r understanding of which  
difficulties service and application development teams are facing, address these concretely, and roll 
out these learnings to other application teams or cast them into reusable technology components. 
Successful development models em erge and others  in our ecosystem  can adopt them .  
Application developers at SAP need to fulfill many centrally defined requirements , including our 
established product standards . This applies to both greenfield and brownfield projects, as well as to 
acquisi tions that become part of SAP. In a collaborative fashion, the North Star Architecture  
maintains the architectural best practice to fulfill these requirements.  
This paper  is an opportunity to lay out a long -term vision for technical activities that guides us on our 
continuous journey towards a true enterprise cloud company. We believe  that SAP can become a 
truly service -oriented company,  in which teams that provide service s are empowered to be 
innovative and autonomous ; while at the same time following  clear guid ance  on how to best invest 
their time and resources to maintain  the focus on our customer s.  
Background and Motivation  
In former times , the days of SAP R/3, develop ment was based on a database -centric integration 
paradigm. Development was transaction -based and always ensured ACID consistency with real -time 
effectiveness (for example, data saved in the logistics module in one transaction was available in the 
financial s module immediately). No integration middleware was needed, everything was in a single 
monolithic system (or system group).  
©2020 SAP SE – Internal    13 
  
 
SAP’s North Star Architecture  Due to the growing complexity of business system landscapes and an increasing data volume, more 
and more integration effort was nee ded. Today, the complete data of global businesses is spread all 
over the world, and worldwide access to this distributed data is needed. This has given rise to 
thoughts  about  data consistency and latency . Thus, the idea of distributed systems was born – and 
as a final consequence  – the cloud.  
In the cloud, customers delegate the risk of operations to cloud application vendors . These need to 
be more efficient, because in the cloud , the barrier to switch to another software vendor becomes 
very low. To address these efficiency challenges, new technology paradigms arose, for example 
containerization, service meshes, and microservices – all targeted to solve scalability issues.  
“... These techniques enable loos ely coupled systems that are resilient, manageable, and 
observable. Combined with robust automation, they allow engineers to make high -impact changes 
frequently and predictably with minimal toil. . ..” [Cloud Native Computing Foundation].  
The new architectu re paradigms guarantee non -blocking, resilient, and scalable services. We pay in 
redundancies in the form of stateless services and replicated data. At a first glance this seems to be a 
disadvantage – in reality, it increases the performance drastically as  it enables parallel processing, 
which also solves another issue of monolithic systems: the scalability of the solution. If one single 
functionality of a monolithic software component needs more CPU power, one must scale the 
complete system – in a microser vice architecture the functionality can be scaled independently.  
Meanwhile, there is an increasing number of independent and self -contained business applications 
based on the cloud native development paradigm. These heterogeneous cloud applications are 
deployed in different data centers of several hyperscalers. However, the customers expect them to 
be integrated comparable to a monolithic software solution.  
Within SAP's huge portfolio of business applications, the Intelligent Enterprise (IE) Program  focuse s 
precisely on  this integration experience in business processes , to ensure that all business 
applications work together as one single new application. Consequently, integration of (at least) 
SAP's own cloud solutions is one of the most important topics to  solve. It is the main driver for our 
customers’ and developers ’ experience.  
In fact, our customers' integration costs for “implementing SAP” (including our cloud applications) 
have skyrocketed and this has been identified as a leading concern by both DSAG and ASUG 
members. Even large partners like IBM, Accenture, and Deloitte experience difficulties in staffing SAP 
implementation projects , due to the broad range of expertise required to cover all involved 
products. They want to work with "One SAP", rat her than with something that feels like the p roducts 
of several  different companies. Therefore, we need to focus on measures that bring our solutions 
closer together.  
How to read  this Paper ? 
As far as the working model and the foundational  technology considerations are concerned, this 
paper contains binding guidance. The key guidance points are summarized at the top of each section 
and explained within the section, either in the prose or in a dedicated sub -section. Binding guidance 
uses the  words “MUST”, “SHOULD”, “MAY”, “RECOMMEND” (in capital letters), etc. in accordance 
with IETF’s RFC 2119 . The usage of the word “mandatory” is equivalent to “MUST”. When 
introducing a “designated” solut ion, this is to be interpreted as a “SHOULD”, with a tendency to 
mak ing this a “MUST” later.  
Nevertheless, executing and evolving the North Star Architecture is a community effort that invites 
everyone across the company to contribute ideas – it is not a t op-down approach.

SAP’s North Star Architecture  Working towards a Common North Star Architecture  
Targeting all SAP developers, product managers, and architects, the North Star Architecture outlines 
the long -term technical objectives for the desired target state and architecture facil itating SAP’s 
overall product strategy. It sets clear guardrails for cross -board technology topics of high strategic 
relevance that drive the product direction and architectures of all LoBs. The North Star Architecture 
is an open and continuous working mod el that involves and leverages the expertise of developers 
and architects across all LoBs within SAP. The goal is to engage all LoBs in discussions on topics 
relevant for them, voice their opinions, and take part in determining the long -term architectural 
vision and strategy across different areas. Lastly, the North Star Architecture follows a 
comprehensive process leading to LoB adoption , operationalized through Technology Guidelines . 
Specifying the North Star Architecture is not a one -off activity. Instead, it will be revised yearly, 
triggered by learnings gained, emerging ideas, and the evolution of external boundary conditions, 
market requirement s, technology trends, as well as constitutional strategic decisions. The long -term 
vision outlined in this paper addresses  the next 3 -5 years  and is meant to be the basis for 
architectural decisions going forward.  
It is the foundation for transforming and translating the given guardrails into more tangible 
architecture documents and aligned concepts. The resulting architecture pieces will contain 
guidelines that are more executable and that address a shorter timeframe than the overall North  
Star document. According to the guidance to “focus on results and adoption”, we aim to achieve 
short -term results, such as having first concepts applied within this year and focusing on incremental 
steps to reach our goals.  
To streamline this journey, ind ividual LoBs might still provide their own detailed North Star papers, in 
alignment with this SAP -wide North Star Architecture. Such papers might describe their individual 
journeys, translating the North Star Architecture into the current state, short -term  goals, and 
actionable activities in a developer -centric language. They can also capture the progress of key 
activities and provide a more in -depth view to developers on how the LoB moves towards the overall 
North Star Architecture target state.  
As of tod ay, many LoBs, such as Concur, Qualtrics, and the T&I LoBs, publish their own detailed 
North Star papers  to guide their internal development. As some North Star papers have been guiding 
developers for years, and as some crucial decisions in this North Star Architecture paper have only 
recently been clarified and aligned, these earlier papers might not yet fully reflect the desired North 
Star Archit ecture target state , but will evolve towards the overall vision in next iterations.  
Going forward , we need to make architectural decisions with a good balance of thoroughness and 
speed, and once we have reached a decision, it must be put into practice as s oon as possible. With 
the North Star Architecture initiative, we  provide actionable advice that moves the needle for the 
entire company. Ultimately , there must be measurable improvements of major KPIs , such as time -to-
market, development efficiency, mainte nance costs, cost of operations, infrastructure costs, 
implementation costs, and customer satisfaction. We should also aim to measure and improve on 
availability metrics , lead time to provision a customer, and frequency of deploying new versions. In 
additi on, we need to  assess how the North Star Architecture  improves the ability of applications to 
deliver features efficiently to compete in their respective markets, and how well it promotes 
capabilities that span applications, such as master data management,  business configuration, unified 
inbox, or workflow capabilities.  
We acknowledge that each LoB within SAP is in a different state and will have a different path to 
achieve the target state. There is no expectation to “rip and replace” existing solutions, b ut to 
achieve convergence over time, with each LoB setting its own pace and prioritizing according to its

ensure individual decisions in each LoB work t owards a common goal. Challenges (technical or 
otherwise) will arise, and we will address them over the course of the North Star Architecture  
timeframe.

A product strategy is only as good as the capability to exec ute on it. Hence, we need to establish a 
sound and comprehensive framework to drive the execution of the North Star Architecture 
definition, refinement , and adoption. The Engineering Senior Leadership Team  (ESLT), headed by 
Jürgen Müller, is the highest ra nked forum where engineering executives conduct technology 
decisions for the whole company. Consequently, the ESLT oversees the North Star Architecture 
initiative, ensures alignment with the overall strategy , and  prioritizes adoption efforts.  
The ESLT also  appoints dedicated representatives of all LoBs to act as Cross -Product Architecture 
Leads (CPA leads). CPA leads in turn appoint CPA working groups for all current and upcoming 
strategic architectural topics covered in the North Star Architecture. As a re sult, there will be 
working groups for infrastructure alignment, containerization/service mesh, security, integration and 
kernel services, data management and analytics, application runtimes , and others. Each group will 
need to  evolve and refine the direct ives of the North Star Architecture into executable concepts and 
guidelines.  CPA leads, in turn, need to ensure that the results are aligned across the working groups.  
While each working group is open for contributors from all LoBs, it also has a designate d lead , and 
lead represent ing all LoBs that are empowered to take decision s and give commitments. The group 
leads, with input from the CPA leads, define a mission around their respective cluster of topics , set 
up expert groups per relevant sub-topic , and plan the envisioned deliverables. Group objectives may 
be short -term (e.g. o ne quarter) or mid -term (e.g. one year). The working group leads guide group 
decision making, choose document editors with editing privileges, moderate discussions, and track 
and report progress. Their main goal is to develop peer -reviewed documents that d escribe the 
architecture at a high level.  
Working groups operate transparently, with open peer reviews and community contributions. They 
must consider inputs from various sources, such as the company strategy and business needs,

activities. As such, they act as an open forum and a s facilitator for know ledge exchange, alignment, 
and decision -making.

execution model  that was successfully implemented in the scope of th e Intelligent Enterprise  (IE)

SAP’s North Star Architecture  Engineering Principl es  
Before we take a deeper look into individual topics, we first provide an overview of key enablers for 
a modern architecture and introduce some basic principles that guide us in our architecture work.  
Architectural and Engineering Excellence  
The trend t hat enabled agile innovation at web scale is the move from monolithic to microservices 
architectures. Many online applications start their life as a monolithic 3 -tier application but then run 
into scalability limits as the application grows large and compl ex. It becomes inflexible and brittle, 
release cycles become longer, code ownership becomes diffused, and technical debt becomes 
unmanageable.  
While not a silver bullet, a microservices architecture helps accelerate an organization's agility. To be 
effect ive, a microservices architecture needs organizational alignment, empowerment, 
accountability, and end -to-end ownership along with loose coupling and strong cohesion between 
systems. Unlike homogenous, tightly coupled, and inflexible monolithic systems, sy stems composed 
of microservices are heterogenous, flexible, and evolutionary.  
However, despite its benefits, a microservices architecture trades one set of problems for another. 
Managing a large distributed system of hundreds or thousands of microservices  and the 
communication between them, securing them, and dealing with their failures are non -trivial 
problems. While it is an undisputed decision to transition from big monoliths to microservices, SAP 
still has many details to figure out and a steep learnin g curve  to climb .  
Engineering Excellence in a Cloud Context  
Engineering excellence for a web -scale business is the outcome of certain practices and principles.  
• “You build it, you run it” is a basic principle of an y organization that follows a service -oriented 
model.  A combination of DevOps and Site Reliability Engineering  (SRE ) is practiced 
systematically, using observability and automation. DevOps is used by teams to own the 
deployment and runtime management of their services in production. SR E teams use 
monitoring, metrics, and automation to manage the overall health of the platform including 
availability, latency, performance, and capacity.  
• CI/CD and automation are used across infrastructure and application lifecycle.  
• Immutable infrastructur e is managed through infrastructure as code (“cattle, not pets”).  
Ideally, the entire stack is software -defined and thus a full landscape can be spawned with 
very little manual effort.  
• Microservices, APIs, and asynchronous messaging are used to achieve loo se coupling and 
strong cohesion.  
• Security is ensured by defense in depth, identity and access management, principles of least 
privilege, and encryption of data at rest and in motion.  
• Maintain uniformity, portability, and standardization across environments. Environments 
should not have special one -offs that result in different software for different places.  
 
Development Flexibility, Productivity, and Predictability  
SAP developers are empowered to effectively deliver improvements and results for the intelligent 
suite. The key trade -off is to identify a “happy path” to quickly deliver results for standard 
development tasks, while retaining the flexibility to deviate from this path when n ecessary to push 
the boundaries on innovation. With increased development productivity and velocity, we must 
ensure that changes made to systems yield predictable outcomes. Developers should be confident 
that their incremental changes do not jeopardize oth er areas of the system. To achieve this goal, we 
©2020 SAP SE – Internal    18 
  
 
SAP’s North Star Architecture  need to look at the entire developer experience, think about how we can benefit from local 
development environments and harmonized tools, and explore the automated setup of landscapes 
where developers can te st and experiment.  Through tools, we can also motivate certain usage 
patterns. For example, a development platform should have  the ability to directly apply a boilerplate 
template to try out a certain approach  (e.g. , Spring Boot CQRS -flavored microservice backend with 
Angular Fiori Frontend) with minimal effort . Frequently used patterns for service and application 
development within SAP must be readily available in platform cockpits or developer portals , moving 
away from the fragmented tool landscape we have today . This must be achieved for the core 
development tasks such as compliant build, security compliance , and source code management. 
Over time, this will streamline the approaches, improve quality , and increase developer productivity.  
Scaling: to a user base of 1BN+ users across the entire suite : Considering the aggregate numbers of 
end users and growth across our systems, we need to serve over one billion users spanning multiple 
deployment regions and applications. Scaling does not only include the automatic and load -based 
upscaling of service and application instances and resources, but also the automatic and load -based 
downscaling  (even to zero) of these instances and their resources. SAP will only scale cost-efficiently 
and effectively , if this two -way elasticity exists. Of course, this also applies to  SAP’s own services , 
where cost-effectiveness  must also be a design goal . 
Scaling and elasticity are relevant on both micro and macro levels. Each application is accountable 
for the scalab ility of its components. Business processes are planned, configured, and executed 
across multiple systems requiring inter -application communication and coordination. On the macro 
level, the intelligent suite must offer integration patterns for scalable and  asynchronous 
communication, reducing the need for coordination to a minimum or even to zero. Given SAP’s 
global reach, integration concepts must include the possibility of over a billion end users and include 
scalability on all levels as a first -class con cept . And while  this does not necessarily mean “auto -
scaling”, it is most certainly a part of the puzzle.  
Scaling: from SME to LE : The macro domain must provide a complete multi -tenant environment, 
allowing a completely automated setup of new tenants. Whil e there are many options to fulfill 
multitenancy requirements, we need to choose those multitenancy patterns that reduce the 
marginal cost for new tenants to near zero. Together with scalability requirements, we should be 
able to use the same products and architecture for very small tenants (such as Small or Medium 
Enterprises) and large enterprises. Automated  and load -based up - and downscaling of service and 
application instances and resources will play a key role in delivering these qualities.

SAP’s North Star Architecture   Architects MUST use industry -standard software engineering approaches (such as TAM or

and communication basis, existing applications and services MUST also provide

Macro and Micro Considerations  
Cloud architectures that are as complex and heterogeneous as SAP’s intelligent suite are best 
addressed on two different levels: the micro level and the macro level. The macro level (“big 
picture”) defines binding rules and regulations for integration, int eroperability , and shared rules. The 
micro level is about streamlining how individual applications are built, where – due to the 
encountered heterogeneity – guidelines and advice work better than binding rules.  
The unit of delivering value within the intel ligent suite is a service. We rely on methodologies such as 
Domain Driven Design (DDD) to define a common ubiquitous language that facilitates 
communications across engineering teams. DDD can also guide the architecture and design process 
with tactical pat terns that make it easier to conquer the challenges encountered on both levels.  
On the Macro  level, fixed and non -negotiable rules and 
boundary conditions, and common integration 
approaches are imposed on services. These may 
include prescribed patterns, technologies, and API 
harmonization as well as non -functional requirements, 
such as service availability or usability. The North Star 
Architecture  defines the macro -level guidance an d may 
be augmented with additional concepts that are not 
currently reflected in the Intelligent Enterprise 
program.  
The macro level includes patterns for identity 
management and lifecycle principles, prescribes 
onboarding APIs that each service needs to im plement, 
and offers central services like an event log, 
operational data collection , or user management.  
The North Star Architecture  collects requirements and best practices from SAP’s development 
community and harmonizes these into macro -level APIs and guidelines and triggers the creation of 
new services where necessary. LoB participation to reach macro -level guidelines for all partic ipating 
LoBs is key. Once agreed, they are binding.  
The Micro level is the internal domain of each service or application within the intelligent suite. 
Often , a service itself also c onsist s of several microservices . To the outside world, these are not 
visible. Instead, a service is fully defined to the outside world by its “hardened” APIs and events  – 
secure, well -designed, well -documented, and governed by SLAs in terms of latency, availability, and 
throughput. The responsibility for architecture, design, a nd implementation on the micro level falls 
with the providing LoB and leaves a high degree of freedom to the LoB.  
Within our diverse organization , there are no one -size-fits-all solutions on the micro level, and one of 
the fundamental questions a team tha t plans to deliver a new service must answer is which degrees 
of freedom they need and desire. While each service is unique and provides specific capabilities that

SAP’s North Star Architecture  Cloud Native Development  
Before we dive directly into specific tools and technologies, it is important to describe the desired 
qualities and how to achieve them conceptually. Officiall y, “cloud  native ” is defined3 as: “… loosely 
coupled  systems that are resilient , manageable , and observable . Combined with robust automation , 
they allow engineers to make high -impact changes frequently and predictably  with minimal toil ”. 
Within SAP’s context , at least the following aspects are relevant for engineering teams4: 
Automation  is the key enabler for an agile, high -quality shipment of software into production. This 
requires fully automated continuous integration, delivery and deployment pipel ines with which 
teams can deploy their source code safely into production as often as possible. Leading teams in 
product engineering are capable of deploying their solutions into production multiple times per day 
without any planned downtimes , using zero -downtime deployment techniques. Together with 
resilient  design (see below) this may result in what we call “OK -ish” availability  (i.e., enabling 
effective availability between 99.8% -99.9%).  
Evolvability  is a key skill in the cloud. Based on automation, it enables teams to start small and 
release a product early based on a different architectural assumption than a large -scale solution 
requires. For example, teams can start with more coarse -grained service s in their first versions , thus  
accelerating their initial release and refactor their services later into smaller ones, once adoption 
sets in and workload characteristics (e.g., write/read throughput) are clearer so that teams can 
optimize their services w hen it is relevant. This avoids premature optimizations slowing down go -to-
market and unnecessarily increasing TCO.   
Multitenancy , defined as a shared system serving multiple tenants, is a key design requirement to 
enable constantly decreasing infrastructu re costs (in fixed provisioned infrastructures) and to 
decrease variability costs in production. It is required that every software layer and every technology 
acknowledge multitenancy (i.e., UI, application code, database, dependent services) in a consiste nt 
and, preferably, transparent way. This enables application developers to make less mistakes at 
design  time where underlying technology handles multitenancy itself and provides a consistent 
consumer experience at runtime.  
Scalability  refers to the ability to accommodate different loads by adding or removing resources, and 
elasticity refers to the ability to adapt resources dynamically. Both are, like multitenancy, important 
cloud requirements to achieve low infrastructure costs (TCO) by allowing the application to adapt to 
different workloads.  
 To achieve these qualities, applications MUST be designed stateless whereas any state must 
be outsourced to managed backing services such as databases or caches. Applications and 
services MUST  also choose a design that scales to encountered load, data volume, etc. and 
MUST make proper use of cloud -based elasticity ( up and down scaling).  
 
Observability  of cloud  native applications is of utmost importance. With multitenant solutions, 
debugging i n production is hard and the real state of the application is in flux. Thus, it is necessary 
that applications write comprehensive log information on the right level of granularity – not just to 
fulfil l product standards (e.g. , audit logs) but to easily an alyze application failure states ex -post. In 
addition, traceability between services as well as between services and end users (e.g., based on

SAP’s North Star Architecture  correlation IDs) is an absolute necessity. Furthermore, applications should be easily monitorable at 
runtime to d etect non -application failures such as slow networks or unresponsive downstream 
systems.  
Resilience  is key to reach higher levels of availability  at runtime. New applications on SAP Cloud 
Platform should embrace resilience patterns (e.g., bulkheads, circui t breakers) that allow for isolating 
failure units so that a failure in one part ( e.g., component, application module, tenant, micro -service, 
service dependency, etc.)  does not affect the business function of another co -located tenant. In a 
similar vein, a pplications shall apply asynchronous or event -based patterns to decouple from their  
dependent systems (e.g., S/4HANA) and services (e.g., Kernel and Business Services) whenever 
possible to make less assumptions about their availability at runtime.  
Even hig her cloud qualities could be achieved through additional efforts such as regional data 
distribution, automatic failover, highly redundant infrastructure, or ephemeral runtimes as made 
popular by the serverless movement. However, we need to understand that these higher qualities 
are currently not achievable with SAP Cloud Platform  and thus are considered the next step in our 
journey to provide cloud  native solution s. Nevertheless, already today we work closely with the 
technology teams to identify options su ch as utilizing hyperscaler infrastructures to provide 
additional cloud qualities.  
SAP One Domain Model  
A key pillar of the successful integration and extension of applications within the intelligent suite  is 
the alignment on a shared and consistent data model. Integration scenarios and cross -product 
analytics rely on the ability to combine data from service s that have different data models and data 
storage locations. This activity is a foundational effort to develop a working ecosystem around our 
solutions and their business objects, which ultimately increases customer value and thus loyalty.  
To achieve thi s ambitious goal, the Domain Model Alignment (DMA) project was initiated. Its 
mission, driven by modelling and domain experts from all business areas, is to define a single, 
aligned and unified SAP One Domain Model (ODM).  The focus is on identifying the most important 
business objects in the scope of the end-to-end processes of the Intelligent Enterprise, defining and 
describing their semantics, and driving the cross -LoB alignment.  
Currently, data objects can have differing attributes (names, types, lengths) for the same semantic 
meaning in different systems. This complicates the mapping of attribute values to one another, so 
that it cannot be automated easily. Aligned domain models are an enabler f or consistent APIs and 
reduced dependency on middleware to translate data structures and values.  
The aligned models in the One Domain Model  will initially cover only a certain part of the exposed 
data models. The DMA process initially focuses on all data o bjects (master data, transactional data , 
and configuration data, including code lists)  that are relevant in integration  scenarios  – i.e., shared 
between at least two applications .  
The ODM is to be the main point of integration , spanning the digital core and all SAP cloud LoB 
applications. Most LoB applications will keep their internal model but maintain mappings  to ODM. 
All LoB applications are expected to provide ODM -compliant mappings and the required integrations 
to the Kerne l Services enabling the ODM -based integration.  
ODM aims to be  easier to comprehend, use , and extend  compared to the applications’ native 
models , making it easier for third parties to develop not only for single LoB solutions, but generically 
with SAP’s por tfolio. A common data model for integration reduces our internal, as well as the 
customers’, costs and efforts around integrations.  ODM is the foundation for two additional 
programs: Master Data Integration (MDI) and SAP Graph, discussed later in  this pape r. 
©2020 SAP SE – Internal    22 
  
 
SAP’s North Star Architecture  Applications shall expose the One Domain Model  
ODM defines our common “language” of exchange within the intelligent suite and consequently also 
for the North Star Architecture . For inter -application communication, the ODM also defines the APIs 
of the ex ternal interfaces of an application (APIs and Events).  
 Therefore, applications MUST expose the respective domain objects on their system’s API 
surface using the standardized ODM format. If possible, applications SHOULD use the ODM 
entities in the entire stack to harmonize the entire experience beyond the API layer. More 
detailed patterns to facilitate this approach – especially related to “full -stack microservices” 
that can also provide UI micro components – will be created over time.  
Event -Driven  Architecture  
Event -driven architectures address tight coupling issues by introducing events to minimize the 
assumptions between a service provider and its consumers . Instead of talking about a service 
provider and a service consumer, they introduce an ev ent publisher and a receiver connected by a 
messaging infrastructure  that provides a message channel  as depicted in Figure 5.  
This decoupling between event publisher and receiver is important for a microservice architecture to 
achieve a scalable and flexible solution. It implies that publisher and receiver do not mak e any 
assumptions5 about each other  – for example,  about availability, internal representations, or 
protocol.  
Event -driven architectures support the decoupling of publishers and subscribers of events regarding 
time, location , and number of participants.  
• Time means that publishers and subscribers can execute asynchronously and could join or 
leave the exchange at an y point in time without any disruption to the system.  
• Location means that they can run in the same as well as in different (remote) systems.  
• Decoupling in terms of number of participants  relates to the fact that there could be one 
publisher exchanging events with exactly one subscriber, but as well thousands or zero 
publishers or subscribers.  
These types of decoupling foster qualities which are associated with event -driven architectures  – for 
example,  scalability  – because asynchron ous code  avoids blocked threads and promotes resilience in

protocol layer.

isolation, so that failures of one participant in a n event -driven architecture do not harm others.

to provide interoperability ,

SAP’s North Star Architecture  SAP’s Business Technology Platform  
Today, many problems are still solved separately by each application and its respective stack. 
Fortunately, many LoBs have started to modernize their respective stacks with cloud native and 
microservice patterns. Therefore, especially now, we encourage cro ss-LoB knowledge exchange and 
we SHALL share architecture and designs to leverage synergies. This requires common approaches 
and solutions to integrate or harmonize on all layers of the existing vertical stacks. If we build the 
next generation of intellige nt suite applications in a siloed approach again, we will not meet the 
needs of our customers.  
We need to commit ourselves to the Business Technology Platform (BTP) as our one platform.  
The North Star Architecture covers the architectural target state of  the entire intelligent suite, 
including defining key elements that comprise the BTP . We identified  the key architectural  topic 
areas  for applications and services where  alignment to the principles  of the North Star Architecture  
and technologies in the BTP  will take place .

SAP’s North Star Architecture  Transition to One Integrated Platform  
The key change in architecture strategy is from “Autonomous Vertical Stacks” to building on “One 
Platform” to address the current heterogeneity and complexity due to numerous technology stacks.  
Currently, applications – often due to their heritage – are built on independent, application -specific 
vertical stacks as depicted on the left side of Figure 7. Stack  refers to the end -to-end choice of 
technologies, ranging from UI framework via application framework down to database technology 
and underlying infrastructure6.  
Each of these stacks comes with its own set of supporting platform services, such as build and deploy 
pipelines, monitoring , etc., solved in an autonomous fashion. Only few services from the SAP Cloud 
Platform are used in this picture, mainly on an as -needed basis or when it is mandated.  
From this current  state  (on the left side of Figure 7), we want to transition to one architectural 
approach, based on our one Business Technology  Platform  (target  state  on the right side of Figure 7) 
where we build and deliver our software , where customers integrate and extend and where 
partners can bring unlimited innovation to the ecosystem .  
The incremental  investments into the common platform will 
deliver value over time, as more and more functionalities are 
transitioned over to it and the legacy stacks shrink. The 
existing applications also bring their legacy onto the platform, 
as they adopt common service s (starting with the Kernel 
Services) and even common deployment and operations 
approaches, such as Kubernetes. This will, over time, enable a 
smooth transition to a new cloud native development 
approach, while already reaping efficiency gains on key 
aspec ts early in the process.  
Business Technology Platform Planes  
The platform i s fully service enabled. There are three  main groupings of services  (“planes”)  which  will 
be described in the following sections.  
Application Plane  
From an architectural perspective  the application plane  provides an end -to-end, user -centric 
experience and focuses on the business domain as defined by the SAP One Domain Model, as well as 
on the business processes, which need to be flexibly customizable. The business domain model , 
busin ess domain services , and business  processes based on the customer’s specific landscape are the 
cornerstones of the application plane . The application plane  is the place where a user -facing

SAP’s North Star Architecture  integrated look and feel across applications and services can be achieved , while the transition to a 
more harmonized and efficient technical underpinning can happen “behind the scenes”. By capturing 
all entry -points to the intelligent suite, it serves as the umbrella (or “ strangler ”) of both the “old and 
new world”.  
To make SAP’s customers eventually perceive the intelligent suite  as tangible, we need to make it a 
real product experience. By viewing the intelligent suite as a product, the application plane  can 
redefine the experience we deliver to our end users and partners. For example, by applying design 
thinking to the user -facing channels, we can make a leap on the experience we deliver, including an 
API-first approach based on curated exposure to ensure quality (such as in SAP Graph). We can also 
completely rethink our approach to a partner ecosystem , based on a common extensib ility approach  
that enables  an ecosystem play based on a common marketplace/store. As such, putting an application 
platform as a gatekeeper to the end user is a major step towards a unified suite experience.  
Data Plane  
From an architectural perspective t he data plane provides semantic and consistent access to all 
enterprise data across SAP systems/services, manifesting core principles of enterprise data 
management in the cloud. It combines SAP’s entire portfolio of data -related Cloud services into a 
single logical plane to provide, integrate, derive, and analyze data to enhance the value for the 
customer. It contains data management solutions, like managed SAP HANA services, SAP Analytics, 
Data Intelligence, Master Data Integration, and more. Data management  technologies will mainly be 
consumed by applications as managed services in the future; therefore,  the data plane implements 
cloud qualities including elasticity, high availability, and cost efficiency to achieve the needed 
acceptance by applications.  
Details on the concepts  and building blocks  of the data plane are introduced in the Data 
Management and Analytics  chapter later in this document.  
Foundational Plane  
From an architectural perspective a ll kinds of capabilities are delivered as services – along all planes  
defined in the North Star Architecture: Data Plane, Kernel, Business and Technology Services.  
 To achieve a self -determined, scalable service -based offering, every service or application 
MUST be driven by an API -first approach and ensure macro  rules are followed to achieve 
the desired discoverability and consumption experience (including committed SLAs, well -
specified interfaces, and quality documentation). This is a key enabler  of a development 
model for a large, distributed organization.  
It is important to understand that while a solid technological foundation is required to enable such a 
service -oriented and API -first approach, we also need to revisit development processes and 
organizational issues that slow down its success.  
Service Manage ment  
The most crucial platform capabilities revolve around enabling service consumers and providers to 
“plug into” the platform’s foundational plane : by finding services, applications , and their APIs in a 
central catalog / repository, retrieving key information, documentation, API definitions, and 
programmatically accessing the respective life cycle management (if applicable). These capabilities 
will need to stay in focus for continuous  refinement, to drive forward our ability to become truly

SAP’s North Star Architecture  service -oriented and make the discovery, consumption , and providing of APIs and services effective 
and delightful7.  
Technical components , such as the service mesh as well as a consolidated service  management, 
metering, API and event -driven architecture strategy , are foundations for a services -based platform 
architecture. It should also be clear that services are always built in a quality that is ready for 
external consumption and is competitive in key dimensions, such as usability and cost.  
 Kernel Services  are mandatory reusable technical services, which MUST be used by every 
application, if the corresponding capability is needed8. Whenever a solution does not use 
them, integration, user experience, or end -to-end business processes and scenarios will 
break. The Kernel Services are described in more detail in section “ Kernel Services ”. 
The foundational plane includes services that provide infrastructure capabilities to developers across 
both the hyperscalers as well as SAP’s data centers (“GCS PlusOne stack”). Building on top of Docker 
containers and Kubernetes technology, it provides an “open build -on” development model that 
allows for a high degree of flexibility when building cloud native software. Additional managed 
runtimes, such as ABAP runtime, Neo runtime, or Cloud Foundry runtime serve the needs of specific 
developer personas.  
Development Services  
The Development services  provide development tools and runtimes for the various developer 
personas, ranging from cloud  native developers to professional users. Here, we focus to p rovide 
components and tools as services that improve the developer experience and drive productivity, 
while ensuring guardrails of the architecture such as Technology Guideline conformance, multi -cloud 
capability, and global deployment are built -in to the development model. While the development

SAP’s North Star Architecture  services  provide solutions for greenfield development, it also addresses heritage workloads in

Here, the cloud native development approaches are the tools of choice, as  they provide the highest 
degree of flexibility to address the needs of existing applications as well as to build the platforms of 
the future. As such, cloud native development is a key enabler to build platform capabilities for the 
other development perso nas. We must truly embrace cloud native concepts such as continuous 
delivery and integration, service orientation and microservices, and serverless principles to drive 
scalability. But also , non-technical aspects of cloud native, such as pervasive measurem ent, 
metering, pay -per-use, being data -driven, as well as a relentless focus on the end user and developer 
experience through all channels, are paramount.  
SAP also needs to provide extensions to commonly used programming frameworks and appropriate 
tool su pport for frequently used programming languages to ease the consumption of services from 
the platform. To achieve a common user experience, multiple UI frameworks are provided as well.  
Programming Model Layers  
Applications featuring all advantages of clou d-based services require full utilization of cloud -native 
patterns to satisfy both the requirements of SAP’s customers and internal developers regarding 
development and ops efficiency. The foray into the cloud environment comes with intrinsic 
complexities:  Typically, cloud services consist of multiple components and business processes run 
across multiple component boundaries. Thus, distributed systems require an understanding of 
distributed, eventually consistent processes, distributed data models and of an  overarching 
orchestration.  
The community of cloud developers – both SAP internal as well external – is required as a whole to 
adapt to the skill set necessary to build scalable and profitable (low TCO) services fulfilling the Suite 
Qualities SAP’s custome rs expect.  
While we provide layered solutions which trade flexibility against opinionated patterns, internally 
SAP developers must be comfortable with each layer and capable of working as cloud -native 
practitioners.  
Any task accomplished on one layer of th e stack may always be accomplished identically on a deeper 
layer with more tunable, granular control. Part of development and architectural planning is 
understanding where and how to make the trade -offs in choosing the right place in the continuum.  
It is n ot realistic nor economical to expect each and every developer to be capable of inventing, for 
example reliant enterprise -ready data integration patterns within an existing application stack. At 
the same time, it is also not feasible to build an all -encomp assing abstraction layer capable of 
shielding off all characteristics of distributed systems. The reality will be a natural mix of the two 
extremes, with each developer having a mixture of tasks scattered over all layers. Performance and 
resiliency will al ways require an advanced understanding of the foundations. For the next years we’ll 
need more developers understanding and programming in the lowest layer.

SAP’s North Star Architecture  Putting all these assumptions together, the Business Technology Platform needs to support the three 
levels of programming models shown in Figure 10. 
These models will b e described in detail in the next sections.  
Flexible Full -Control Model  
Multiple decades ago, SAP has had a deep understanding of business processes and developed a 
ground -breaking set of standard products centered around SAP ERP catering to customers’ nee ds. In 
the cloud era, it is our task to invent novel processes utilizing all benefits of distributed systems to 
develop the next -generation Cloud ERP. The better we embrace the non -reducible characteristics of 
distributed systems into our business solution s the more successful our new services will become in 
terms of scalability, security, TCO, etc.  
Thus, business application development is cloud native development.  
In the next years we will see a great need to invest into the cloud -native foundations of ou r 
applications and a significant part of the developers will be required to develop the underlying tools 
and patterns. In order to do so they will require a fully flexible environment allowing them to tackle 
general problems with the full freedom the use c ase requires. At this level, developers also have the 
unlimited capability of cost control, i.e. to use those patterns and technologies reducing the overall 
TCO of all development levels to a minimum.  
Cloud -Native Application Integration Patterns  
Distribut ed processes across new and existing products and their subcomponents will lead to 
distributed data, channeled through message busses and event logs and accessible in a data mesh. 
The distributed data model will become the core of application and service i ntegration scenarios. 
The notion of “eventual consistency” needs to be deeply designed into the architecture and will also 
be part of the user experience.

SAP’s North Star Architecture  Cloud -Native Application Foundation  
Handling of centrally defined aspects – security, observability,  metering, etc. – into all incoming and 
outgoing traffic of all services will produce the same patterns over and over again in multiple 
services. Additionally, typical integration tasks with Kernel Services like eventing, logging, audit 
logging etc. call f or a uniform handling as well. Dealing with these rather non -functional aspects 
bloats the code base in each service making it unnecessarily complex to develop and maintain.  
With the help of a Service Mesh on top of an opinionated K8S/Serverless environmen t, these 
recurring tasks can be outsourced, simplifying the creation of microservices without compromising 
on cloud qualities.  
Istio as a Service Mesh implementation is described in detail in the Service Mesh  section of this 
document. Service Meshes also provide an abstraction layer to older, retrofitted monolithic 
components that provide instant value from reuse.  
High -Level Coding Model  
Each application has its individua l aspects making it unique. On the other hand, every SAP 
application has aspects it shares with many or even all other SAP applications. For such recurring 
tasks SAP has developed and will continue to develop differentiating tools offering higher -layer 
patterns and convenience functions reducing the overall effort and also the variety of local solutions. 
Such convenience functions are best offered in form of a set of modularized open -sourced libraries 
avoiding lock -in. While the platform is defined by its A PIs at each layer, such libraries can facilitate 
more rapid adoption9. Through open source or inner source, acceleration without the burden of 
maintenance is achieved. The maintenance task is centralized and partially also outsourced from 
SAP.  
The success  of these libraries depends on their ability to flexibly mix in other libraries or own 
solutions according to business requirements. Example libraries are an open -sourced and 
modularized version of CAP, ABAP on K8s, RAP, or UI5. The libraries are designed as such to build a 
middle ground, a compromise, between full flexibility and the low/no -code environment.  
Which approach to take – the general, flexible or the specialized opinionated one – is a clear 
business decision by the development team: while conve nience functions allow quick solutions to 
recurring problems, they at the same time consequently limit the application programmers’ 
freedom. For certain customer requirements it will be essential to use the full expressiveness of a 
programming language. Fo r such use cases it is acceptable to have a lower development velocity in 
exchange for a higher level of control – e.g. cost control or performance optimization. Libraries need 
to be not only provided in older, well -established languages but also in modern  languages that have 
gained favor in recent years and are easier to find staff and expertise in.  
Over the course of the next years, an additional efficiency gain can be achieved by reusing services 
multiple times in different application contexts. The set of such reuse services will comprise the 
Business Technology Platform. These services are by definition cloud native services as they need to 
fulfill strict SLAs, which are major criteria in an architect’s service selection process. Examples are 
end-to-end response time, elasticity, pay -per-use, zero downtime, single -entry -point for APIs, 
security, cost etc.  
 
9 Yet, they are not the contract with the consumer. The contract is always defined at the API level.
