SAP’s North Star Architecture  Low/No -Code Model  
Next to the development tasks themselves, there is also a need for a low or no -code environment. 
Such an environment is partner or cu stomer specific and utilizes underlying application services to 
offer these high -level (typically graphical) tasks. The simplicity of its usage does not correlate with 
the simplicity of the implementation under the hood. It is acceptable to use such a laye r to “set up” 
an environment for a business app layer project or native project with regards to patterns, 
endpoints, etc.  
Typically, the low/no -code layer is used for graphical workflow definition, business process 
modeling, creation and maintenance of for ms and themes, UI customization or business domain 
modeling, i.e. to configure, customize and extend standard service behavior.  More details can be 
found in “ UI Develop er Experience ”. 
The usage of the low - to no -code layer is not limited to partners and customers though. The 
environment can also be used SAP -internally to e.g. define multiple variations of the same process 
types next to the external use cases mentioned above.

SAP’s North Star Architecture  Runtime Environments , Containers , and Kubernetes  
This chapter discusses the runtime foundation and principles of the North Star Architecture . 
Guidance  Summary : 
• Kyma ’s opinionated K8S approach should be used in “open build -on” scenarios . 
• All Runtimes (CloudFoundry, Kyma, ABAP) MUST run on K8S . 
• All services (Kernel -, Business -, etc.) MUST  be consumable on all runtimes .  
• Platforms and applications  MUST run on K8S . 
• Gardener MUST  be used  for multi -cloud K8S  use cases . 
• Istio Service mesh MUST be adopted  in K8S clusters . 
• Private Cloud approach MUST be  based on Gardener . 
 
 
Learn more:  
Benefit of Kubernetes  
 
 
To support both the development of new cloud applications and the ongoing renovation of 
traditional apps, a set of comprehensive frameworks and managed runtime en vironments  are 
required. The SAP Cloud Platform Strategy paper  of early 2019 define s both “build -on” and 
“integrate -with” runtime options. Combined with the specified set of Kernel Services, this has the 
potential to form the foundation of the Intelligent Enterprise going forward.  
Currently, on the one hand, SAP Cloud Platform already su pports several managed runtimes: ABAP 
Steampunk, Cloud Foundry (Java, Python, JavaScript), FaaS (JavaScript), and Neo (Java, XS Classic 
JavaScript).  On the other hand, multiple solutions are using native cloud provider runtimes, varying 
from serverless fun ctions and  serverless containers to general compute (VMs) or higher -level 
abstractions with AWS Fargate or Google Cloud Run. When we add Kubernetes to that mix, we have 
two additional parallel offerings there as well:  
• Gardener -managed Kubernetes clusters : offered and managed across all hyperscalers. Gardener 
provides consistent versioning, configuration, and cluster behavior while supporting the latest 
version of Kubernetes and all alpha features, uniform API for cluster management across all 
infrastructur es.  
• Cloud -provider -native Kubernetes offerings  (GKE, AKS, EKS, and ACS): nicely integrated with the 
respective hyperscaler portfolio of services, typically support older versions of Kubernetes and do 
not allow the use of alpha features. Every offer has a different API for cluster provisioning and 
subsequent management, varying in behavior, but integrated with the respective cloud IAM 
infrastructure.  
The primary interest of each cloud provider is to lock its users with a combination of services and 
runtime  options, nicely integrated. At the same time, a vital interest for SAP is to keep a significant 
portion of its applications as independent from the underlying infrastructure as possible, carefully 
assessing which services are acceptable to be dependent on  and which would pose a strategic risk.  
 

©2020 SAP SE – Internal    33 
  
 
SAP’s North Star Architecture   
SAP aims to achieve cross -cloud portability for many of its applications, as well as private/regulated 
market deployment capabilities as a competitive advantage. The most suitable solution for standard, 
newly  developed business applications is to leverage one of the SAP -provided managed runtimes – 
delegating to the respective providing teams the responsibility to make them available across all 
infrastructures.  
 Going forward,  Kubernetes MUST be the default  orchestration layer for all cloud platform 
technologies and applications developed at SAP, managing workloads across various 
infrastructure providers. On top of Kubernetes,  we will establish primary runtime 
environments for a pplications to leverage – depending on their specific needs, load 
scenarios, implementation requirements, and target markets.  
We will classify the different runtime options in three categories:  
• Open Build -on  
We are extending and broadening the category o f “build -on” development with a new “open 
build -on” option to enable the use of containers and Kubernetes, resulting in the needed 
flexibility for our cloud -native developers.  The opinionated development  approach as provided 
by Kyma  SHALL be used as a first choice for cloud native developer personas , giving a well -
defined reference implementation to a “happy path” for Kubernetes -based development . “Open 
build -on” also gives the option to use a vanilla Kubernetes, managed by Gardener.  The approach  
is suitable for both lift -and-shift migration projects and new application development across all 
relevant infrastructures we plan to run on.  
• Managed Build -on 
This approach – to deliver an opinionated runtime  – is referred to as “build -on” (p reviously) or 
“managed build -on” and typically refers to a runtime that is opinionated and fully managed by 
SAP. The developer benefits from a high -level of abstraction from the underlying infrastructure 
and typically does not deal with technical concepts such as virtual machines, compute unit sizing, 
networking and ingress, etc. It provides out -of-the-box integration into all the mandatory Kernel 
Service s. It ensures minimal effort for applications to be developed and deployed , and it  usually 
provides a defined programming model as well as a set of guiding principles for building and 
running applications. It offers a controlled service consumption model within the defined 
boundaries for the specific environment.  
• Integrate -with   
Many  SAP applications already run on  hyperscale cloud providers, using the native compute 
abstractions there. While often cost-efficient, this generates inevitable lock -in and will prevent 
SAP applications from freely expanding into other cloud provider s or provi ding a private cloud 
deployment in the long  run. All Kernel Service s must be consumable in those environments via 
APIs. This approach will as well be the default integration option for third -party applications, 
which we consume as a service and want to int egrate into our portfolio as first -class citizens (for 
example Solex program).  
Following th is classification, we have the following managed runtime options available for SAP 
products to leverage for “ managed build -on” cases.  
• Cloud Foundry  
Cloud Foundry  provides an opinionated cloud environment for developing and running 
applications. Without allowing much flexibility regarding the  underlying network topology or 
storage layers, it established a useful infrastructure abstraction for application dev elopers, 

©2020 SAP SE – Internal    34 
  
 
SAP’s North Star Architecture  enabling them to focus on their apps. SAP Cloud Platform also defined a set of guidelines, 
prescribing how to build a cloud application on Cloud Foundry. Both are consolidated in  the SAP 
Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP)10, covering applic ations written in Java or 
JavaScript. When deployed on the opinionated “build -on” Cloud Foundry environment, 
applications benefit from support for on -premise connectivity and enterprise -grade services, 
developed in the course of the last couple of years. T here is a dedicated effort to modernize and 
transition the existing Cloud Foundry environment (including all available build -packs therein) to 
run on Gardener -managed Kubernetes , extending its life. This transparent transition will 
safeguard the Cloud Foun dry investment made over the years by many applications . 
• Neo  
SAP CP Neo is not being positioned to new customers. On the other hand, to date, it hosts the 
vast majority of the SAP CP customer base, with over  12,000 paying customers. The SAP CP team 
is evaluat ing a transition plan to containerize the existing Neo runtimes (Tomcat, JavaEE Web, XS 
Classic) and transition them to Kubernetes, using the same approach as Cloud Foundry above. 
Alternatively,  the entir e Neo offering might be discontinued , and customers would  have the 
option to migrate to other SAP CP runtime options over time as part of the regular contract 
renewal process.  
• ABAP Steampunk  
Launched in 2018, Steampunk defined the ABAP RESTful Programming  Model, which also 
establishes a set of guiding principles for building cloud applications in ABAP. The Steampunk 
runtime is crucial for extending SAP -ABAP -based solutions in a side -by-side fashion. It also serves 
to enable ABAP experts to transition to th e cloud, stay relevant, and remain in the SAP 
ecosystem. It supports modern development tools like ABAP development tools (ADT) for Eclipse 
for ABAP development – both on -premise and in the cloud. In 2020 , we also hope to see a 
solution to have the classic  ABAP server containerized for improved operational efficiency across 
hyperscalers, allowing to run workloads like S/4 on top of a Kubernetes infrastructure.  
• Kyma Runtime  
The managed SAP Kyma Runtime will provide an integrated, “ open build -on” managed stac k 
based on the underlying Kubernetes infrastructure provided by Gardener, to enable the 
development of container -based, event -driven applications and microservices, tightly connected 
to SAP and partner solutions to facilitate both service development and e xtension use  cases. It 
includes managed Kyma components such as Istio and Knative to provide an opinionated 
approach beyond “plain” Kubernetes. As we will keep the Kubernetes base open and stable, we  
are confident that more of th ese innovations will happen  across the different teams at SAP, 
ideally delivering value and sharing results with the broader developer community across the 
different LoBs.  
As we progress, other more  specific runtime options will emerge – all of them MUST  be based on the 
Kubernetes orchestration  (possibly also employing solutions for integrating managed virtual 
machines where needed).  
 To achieve this, it is

SAP’s North Star Architecture  The “integrate -with” option serves  the purpose of bringing applications into the Intelligent 
Enterprise S uite for a transition period and support new acquisitions, while they reengineer and plan 
their evolution towards the cloud  native North Star Architecture  stack . Exceptional cases that would

Kubernetes Container Orchestration  
Kubernetes is a portable and extensible platform for managing containerized workloads. It facilitates 
declarative configuration and automation. It has evolved into the de -facto industry standard for 
orchestration of container -based workloads. Kubernetes provides a container -centric ma nagement 
environment and orchestrates computing, networking, and storage infrastructure on behalf of 
workloads. That way, it delivers much of the simplicity of Platform -as-a-Service (PaaS) with the 
flexibility of Infrastructure -as-a-Service (IaaS). When ad equately integrated and containerized, SAP 
products can seamlessly transition from one infrastructure to another, reaching private cloud 
environments as well.  
 The guidance  is that a Kubernetes -based approach is now the default option for building 
new platforms, services, and applications. During the North St ar timeframe, the majority of 
our workloads MUST adopt this technology.  
SAP also has a K8s management platform called Gardener  that works across on-premise and cloud 
environments . For workloads  that require  multi -cloud deployment (i.e. need to deploy to multiple 
infrastructure  providers ) Gardener Kubernetes SHALL be used.  Gardener is also designa ted to deliver 
the future approach  for p rivate cloud and restricted markets, as Gardener will be capable to deploy  
to SAP ’s data centers and private environments (VMWare based  or on metal).  A Gardener research 
project will continue to evaluate how low -cost hyperscaler hardware can be employed to run 
Kubernetes workloads in a low -cost approach.  
It is a common practice for infrastructure teams to build and manage large shared Kubernetes 
clusters for all the engineering teams. Teams are typically assigned namespaces to segregate and 
isolate their workloads from each other. The Kubernetes infrastructu re teams deal with running the 
control plane, access control, creating service accounts, the build and deployment pipeline, 
container scanning, container registry, cluster upgrades, and other operational tasks.  
However, with managed platforms such as the ones provided by hyperscalers (EKS, GKE, AKS, ACK) 
and frameworks like Gardener , it is now easy to launch and operate your own Kubernetes cluster. A 
strong service mindset means that a team is empowered to make decisions on all aspects of a 
service , and th at includes the underlying platform (given the constraints of security, compliance , and 
SLAs). A model that enables  teams to provision their own Kubernetes clusters with a managed 
control  plane aligns well with the service mindset. In a shared cluster, teams are not in  control but 
are dependent on other  team s to keep the cluster running, scaled , and secure . A “noisy neighbor” 
could affect your service or even bring the cluster down. But with your own cluster , you are the 
master of your own fate. This is the  recommended approach for teams to follow.  
 Authentication and authorization services are critical to prevent malicious attacks on 
Kubernetes clusters. Usually authentication is managed by the IAM services provided by the 
hyperscaler or the intelligent s uite platform. But for authorization RBAC (role -based access 
control) MUST be enabled on each Kubernetes cluster (the root key must not be used). In a 
multi -cluster scenario, all clusters SHOULD be joined to one or more service meshes.

SAP’s North Star Architecture  A centralized team of Kubernetes experts could add value by providing a set of best practices on how 
to set up Kubernetes clusters. These could be portable approaches (such as Gardener  or Kyma ) that 
run on multiple providers or could be curated templates (such as Terraform templates, AWS 
CloudFormation templates, or AWS Service Catalog items). Both make it easy to:  
• meet compliance requirements (FedRAMP, SOC II, PCI, HPAA, etc .) as needed , 
• integrate with secret stores (Vault, AWS secrets manager) and PKI solutions , 
• integrate with a managed service mesh.  
Tools like Gardener  and Kyma  aim to incorporate these best practices for running containers at scale 
with additional capabilities needed by most developers, such as integrations with SAP services, CI/CD 
pipeline , and a service mesh . Teams can then  focus on  building business applications instead of 
managing clusters.  Given the capabilities of AWS EKS , Google’s GKE , Azure AKS , and Gardener , the 
recommended model is to have dedicated clusters managed by the services, instead of a centralized 
shared cluster.  
Lastly, there is an emerging trend of running serverless workloads on Kubernetes. Open  source 
solutions such as KNative  and AWS Fargate  make it easy to run containers on a Kubernetes cluster 
without w orrying about servers. This is of course attractive, but the solutions have to mature to 
meet requirements of scale, security , and compliance.  SAP has investments in platforms such as 
Gardener, Kyma , and Cloud Foundry. These investments are intended to ach ieve portability, 
extensibility , and ease of use for developers running containerized workloads on multiple cloud 
platforms. We must assess their strengths and weaknesses, popularity across SAP , and their business 
ROI to SAP.  
Container Security  
For all of their convenience and architectural benefits containers can suffer from security 
vulnerabilities like any other software. Containerized applications can have a variety of 
vulnerabilities including bugs, authentication and authorization flaws, insecure libr aries , or malware. 
Containers can be configured to run with elevated or root privileges or they can execute daemons 
that can compromise a system. Many containers in public  container registr ies are known to have 
vulnerabilities. “NIST Special Publication 80 0-190: Application Container Security Guide” is a 
published set of guidelines to manage the security of container images. It serves as a useful starting 
point for security audits.  
 • Based on the NIST recommendation, developers MUST pull images only from t rusted 
sources, such as private container registries. The registries MUST allow only encrypted 
access and MUST have proper authentication and authorization. Federated 
authentication with existing network security controls are recommended. NIST also 
recomme nds maintenance of the image registry, such as cleaning up stale images.  
• Developers MUST manage the security of container orchestration tools like 
Kubernetes by securing the administrative interfaces by using strong multi -factor 
authentication and end -to-end encryption of all network traffic.  
• Containers and container runtimes MUST be scanned for vulnerabilities and patched 
accordingly. There are many container scanning tools. More specific guidance is 
supplied by the Security Working group and SGS.  
• Hardene d container OS images SHOULD be used that follow the NIST standards of 
running a pared -down, container -specific OS that limits the number of installed 
components to the bare minimum. CIS Hardened Images and distroless images are

hardened base images is an important goal for enterprise deployment of containers. 
SAP should ha ve a centralized team for providing tooling and education around 
container security for all developers.

Service Mesh  
A service mesh enables all containerized (and even non -containerized) services to work together in a 
harmonious whole. Service meshes like Istio , Linkerd , and Consul Connect  were created to address 
several problems associated with operating a large number of services within and across data 
centers . 
In this approach, recurring aspects found in distributed systems are not implemented as part of the 
(micro)services anymore but are extracted into a “service mesh layer”. The service mesh exerts tight 
control on all communications to and from the services and can thus address various cross -cutting 
concerns around these connecti ons. A service mesh is ultimately not the introduction of a new 
functionality, but rather a shift in where a functionality is located. For some functionalities (e.g. , 
Service Identity Management), the demand s of the service mesh layer are rapidly increasin g with the 
higher number of microservices contributing to the overall business solution.  
A service  mesh supplies the following capabilities:  
• Service discovery (or integration with an orchestrator like Kubernetes)   
• Automatic load balancing for L7 (Application Layer) traffic – supporting dynamic scaling  
• Control of traffic behavior with ric h routing rules, retries, failovers, and fault injection  
• Policy -based access controls, rate limits, and quotas  
• Observability via automatic metrics, logs, cluster ingress, and egress  
• Traceability through integrated distributed tracing solution (Jaeger, Zipk in, etc.)  
• Secure service -to-service communication in a cluster with strong identity -based authentication 
and authorization  
• Self-healing and better reliability via circuit breaker pattern and dynamic routing  
• Increased network throughput trough smart proxyi ng (e.g. , HTTP/2, GRPC)  
Service meshes are supplied as separate layers usually implemented by supplying a proxy instance, 
called a sidecar, for each service instance. Sidecars handle inter -service communications, monitoring, 

©2020 SAP SE – Internal    38 
  
 
SAP’s North Star Architecture  and security -related concerns. With this, developers can focus on development, support, and 
maintenance for the application code in the services, while operations teams can maintain the 
service mesh and operate the application.  
In the broader  SAP context, the service mesh platform  shoul d address the issues of:  
• Heterogenous implementations with homogenous interfaces:  Applications should be able to 
securely communicate , regardless of the language they are written in and the technologies 
that they are implemented with. The platform’s servic e management capabilities must 
therefore be seamlessly integrated with the service mesh. 
• Trust boundaries and certificate management:  This is a topic for Kernel services, but it is 
conceivable that there are trust zones (such as the SAP Concur trust zone, SAP Qualtrics trust 
zone, S /4HANA  trust zone , and so on). Each trust zone would be managed through a set of 
federated  service mesh es (multiple Control Planes ) that span Kubernetes clusters and VMs. 
Each service mesh would be assigned to an Intermediate Certificate Authority , of which 
multiple may exist for different areas, all based on a Root CA owned centrally by SAP.  
• Federation of service mesh es: Multiple trust zones would have a way to federate across 
service meshes so that a service in one service mesh can call a service in another mesh .  
Currently , Istio seems to be the service mesh with the most extensive set of features. The subject of 
service mesh es is not very mature. There is a lot of work happening in the open  source community 
and all the hyperscalers are also investing in it. This is an area in which SAP must innovate. A service 
mesh platform across SAP’s clou d-based products is essential for achieving the goals of the 
Intelligent Enterprise.  
 The guidance  is therefore that applications and services that build on Kubernetes MUST also 
implement an Istio -based service mesh within their cluster. Later, we will evaluate whether 
to extend the scope to achieve an SAP -wide federated service mesh.

SAP’s North Star Architecture  Application and Service Development  
 
Guidance Summary:  
• We embrace cloud native approaches and over time provide clear blueprints and 
patterns . 
• Java/Spring, Node.JS , and ABAP are primary languages with full tool support . 
• CI/CD become s MANDATORY approach . 
• Source code repositories MUST be open to all in SAP for inner source . 
• Usage of open standards, protocols, and software is the new default choice . 
 
 
 
With new cloud native paradigms, the world of application development is rapidly changing, as more 
technical concerns are surfacing in a way that they concern  application developers. Classically, 
application developers could focus on aspects related to the ir core business domain, such as object 
model design, business logic, constraints and validation as well as the interface to other modules or 
systems. Aspects such as operations or runtime security were usually out of scope.  
With modern approaches such as DevOps (“you build it, you run it”) and service orientation more 
and more technology concerns are surfacing to application developers, reducing the ir focus on the 
business problem. While we must also acknowledge that it will be impossible to shield developers 
from the complexities of the distributed systems problems that arise in cloud -based systems, we 
shall reduce the learning curve and efforts throu gh well -understood shared patterns.  
 
 
First of all, we need to acknowledge that an SAP -tailored best -practice approach to building 
applications in the cloud needs to be refined over time, and that this will be an iterative and 
evolutionary process.  
So fa r, there is common agreement on some high -level goals, practices , and patterns that we want to 
employ. One fundamental agreement is that we want to follow cloud  native patterns both for the 
development of new services and applications, as well as for the d ecomposition of existing monoliths. 
In this chapter, we look into cornerstones of our future approach to cloud native development.  
Domain -Driven Design  
The essence of a business service or application is its business domain, expressed as business domain 
model (objects, entities), business logic, workflow orchestrations, sagas or choreographies, 
validation logic, constraints, events , and so on. Therefore, it is essential that we find a common 
ground to discuss how we approach the building of reliable, stable  business logic in the face of 
changing technical environments. While we will touch some aspects below, in addition we suggest 
that discussions of this topic be based on the approaches and terminologies as used in the “ Domain -
Driven Design ” approach. Here, the strategic patterns, such as employing a ubiquitous language are 
equally relevant as the tactical patterns, such as structuring the domain entities as “aggregates”. 
Therefore, please familiarize yourself with DDD and the literature on it, so we can discuss business -
application -logic -related topics with a common basis.

SAP’s North Star Architecture  Cloud Patterns and Anti -Patterns  
Besides the target qualities of our cloud -native solutions, several patterns have been identified that 
supp ort architects and engineers in re aching  these goals by making deliberate design decisions for 
their application independent of specific tools and technologies. It is important that , in the cloud, 
teams should decide on the best architecture based on their requirements (top -down) instead of 
relying on tools that aim to solve everything (bottom -up). Therefore, we first discuss the patterns 
and refer back to them in later sections of th is paper when discussing concrete tools. The following 
patterns and methods have been found useful and are strongly proposed to achieve the goals from 
above:  
DevOps and its subdiscipline  continuous deployment are methods that propose to put source code, 
infrastructure as code, automated tests, quality checks, etc. into a version control system and move 
every change to any of those artifacts through a so -called continuous delivery pipeline, again 
represented as source code. Such a pipeline is able to build, test, check, and deploy a service with 
zero downtime into production in a fully automated fashion. This does not only reduce manual and 
repetitive efforts, it also heavily improves software quality and leads to always running and 
deployable software. It is  the basis for achiev ing automation  and evolvability , as well as an 
improved availability  (Nicole Forsgren, 2018) .  
 Therefore, Continuous Integration / Continuous Development (CI/CD) practices MUST be 
adopted and used going forward. In addition, the repositories used to manage the source 
code of services and applications MUST be open (read -only) to fellow SAP employees to 
facilitate an inner -source approach – for example, by allowing colleagues to better 
understand other comp onents and even to grant them the ability to open pull -requests.  
Success criteria  are (1) how often teams deploy into production, (2) short lead times from code 
changes to production, (3) how quickly teams can react to production incidents ( mean time to 
recovery = MTTR) and (4) how often a change leads to failures in the pipeline or in production (called 
change failure percentage ) (Nicole Forsgren, 2018) . High -performing teams deploy changes into 
production multiple times per day, have lead times into production of at most one hour, and can 
recover their services at any time in less than an hour. Note that this does not necessarily imply that 
functional changes reach customers when decoupling deployment and release vi a feature toggling.  
Hexagonal Architecture (more 
intuitively: Ports and Adapters)  is a 
pattern that proposes to not organize 
software in simple layers (e.g., UI, app 
server, persistence) but proposes to 
keep the core domain of a service 
completely free fro m any code 
references to the UI, API, the 
persistence provider , or 
incoming/outgoing events.  
Instead, the pattern proposes to model 
the domain in isolation (e.g., in Java as 
POJOs) and write adapters for every 
possible port the domain is driven from (so ca lled primary adapters from the UI or API) and every 
possible port the domain drives (so called secondary adapters for persistence, outgoing events, etc.). 
The name originates from Alistair Cockburn’s initial publication where he used a hexagon to visualize  
three primary and secondary ports . However, th e approach  is not limited to a hexagon.

SAP’s North Star Architecture  In a typical SAP Cloud Platform application11, we may see the following primary ports and adapters: 
(1) an internal API that possibly powers some UI and that changes as  often as UI changes are 
required, (2) a well -documented, well -described public API including event exposure that provides a 
stable contract and changes rarely, (3) other external APIs for other microservices to consume the 
domain as part of the entire sol ution. Note that this does not mean that there cannot be reuse 
among the different kinds of APIs, or one can evolve from the other. Also, all APIs, including internal 
ones, need to follow the accepted standards for security and versioning.  
We also see typical secondary adapters such as (1) interaction with the S/4HANA monolith, (2) a 
local database to store data , and (3) some other third -party services.  
 Please note, that all external APIs MUST be described using machine -readable formats, such 
as OpenAPI, AsyncAPI, GraphQL, or Protocol Buffers/gRPC.  
Generally speaking, the whole trick of this pattern is that the domain can evolve independently from 
its representation in any of the ports whereas the adapters can “buffer” changes over time and serve 
different lifecycle needs, including versioning. In pa rticular, this pattern strongly promotes the 
dependency inversion principle  which postulates that the domain only depends on abstractions and 
not concretions at compile time. Besi des dependency inversion, this pattern also implicitly promotes 
other important software engineering principles known as SOLID  principles. In particular, Liskov’s 
substitution principle  can be easily applied to the adapters as  – for example, a database can be easily 
replaced at runtime using dependency injection. Furthermore, the interface segregation principle  is 
implicitly used as there are many client -specific interfaces instead of one big general -purpose 
interface. All of this is much harder to achieve in a purely layered architecture. A general 
introd uction to this architecture can be found in Uncle Bob’s blog on software architecture .  
This pattern nicely complements the continuous delivery method as it (1) helps  with evolvability  and 
(2) enables  high degrees of automation  and testability  since the core domain can be easily tested 
without requiring access to dependent systems. Finally, this pattern is of great help when decoupling 
from the S/4HANA monolith step -by-step , as it prevents that domain concepts from the monolith 
semantically cre ep into the new SAP CP -based service which, unfortunately, would again tightly 
couple the newly established services on SAP CP to the S/4HANA monolith.  
Services by Lifecycle is a pattern in which  services are designed around behavior, i.e., what a service 
does (its business function) instead of what it knows (its entities and data) (Nygard, 2018) . With this 
pattern, data is not simply stored based on the domain’s entities , but is provided as input to the 
business functions the service offers. Once a consistent state has been reached by calling potentially 
multiple business functions of the same service, the service emits consistent and immutable facts as 
events or documents for consumption by one or more subsequent (micro -)servi ces in order to fulfill 
a business process. These characteristics are a prerequisite for microservices and thus this pattern is 
often used in that context, but also applies to other architectural styles. The pattern helps to (1) find 
consistency boundaries , i.e., all the functions that should be part of a service boundary providing 
stronger atomicity , consistency , isolation , durability  (ACID) guarantees12, (2) find services that can 
evolve and be deployed independently of each other at any time, and (3) allow the exchange of 
consistent, immutable documents between different services to avoid locks, synchroniz ation , and 
other mechanisms which do not work sufficiently in the cloud. The analysis and definition of 
consistency and lifecycle boundaries typically results in one or more microservices that constitute a 
bigger solution to solve a business problem. Hence , it is not about how big or small a service is but

SAP’s North Star Architecture  rather whether a service is consistent in itself and has an own lifecycle that is independent of other 
microservices. You can suspect  a flawed design  whenever  several microservices need to be deployed 
together or consistency across microservices cannot be guaranteed. Services by lifecycles can be 
supported and enriched best with a domain -driven design approach  (Evans, Domain -Driven Design ).  
Event sourcing  is a pattern that complements the services by lifecycle  and hexagonal architecture  
patterns from above. The core idea of event sourcing is that we do not mutate the state of the 
application’s core domain in place. Mutating objects requires additional locking, synchronization, 
and coordination effor ts which are hard or even impossible to achieve in distributed systems aiming 
at high  availability . Event sourcing ensures that all changes to application state are stored as a 
sequence of events. Not only  can we query these events, we can also use the eve nt log to 
reconstruct past states. In a sense, event sourcing roots in the same ideas as the  insert -only writes in 
HANA and the online computation of non -materialized aggregates, now just being expanded to 
several microservices that provide an overarching business process. Event sourcing helps to increase 
(1) availability  as it avoids distributed locks, synchronization, and coordination efforts on mutable 
data across multiple microservices, (2) resilience  since immutable events can be safely distributed, 
thus, even if a component had a non -recoverable outage, its state can be recovered by replaying 
events from other places as every state transition is covered by the sequence of events, and (3) 
observability  since it is easy to determine which events have bee n missed in one service (e.g., due to 
an outage). However, event sourcing also has some challenges. For example, typical message 
infrastructures (e.g., Apache Kafka) only provide at -least failure semantics. This means that if an 
event or its acknowledgment  is lost for some reason between a sender and receiver, the message 
infrastructure will replay the event automatically. As a consequence, the receiver needs to deal with 
de-duplication of events by designing the service in an idempotent  way. In addition, in case of errors 
or inconsistencies between services , compensating transaction s have to be issued  – e.g., using the 
Saga pattern . 
Event sourcing is often combined with the Command and Query Responsibility Segregation (CQRS)  
pattern. The basic idea of CQRS is the separation of interfaces for update and read to maximize 
performance, scalability, and security. In traditional de signs all operations are executed against

only provide at -least failure semantics. This means that if an 
event or its acknowledgment  is lost for some reason between a sender and receiver, the message 
infrastructure will replay the event automatically. As a consequence, the receiver needs to deal with 
de-duplication of events by designing the service in an idempotent  way. In addition, in case of errors 
or inconsistencies between services , compensating transaction s have to be issued  – e.g., using the 
Saga pattern . 
Event sourcing is often combined with the Command and Query Responsibility Segregation (CQRS)  
pattern. The basic idea of CQRS is the separation of interfaces for update and read to maximize 
performance, scalability, and security. In traditional de signs all operations are executed against the 
same representation in a single repository. In CQRS the update interface may be based on document 
models and commands while the read interface is based on highly optimized models such as graphs 
or aggregations.  Further, the read interface can use multiple locally distributed read -only replicas to 
greatly improve resilience and query performance. Separating read from write allows each to be 
scaled appropriately to match load and interface needs optimally. Event sourcing typically uses 
events for the write model as the official source of information. The read model is based on derived 
views, typically highly de -normalized to optimize for UI and application integration. In Financials , 
atomic FI -Documents update the system while users typically query for aggregations such as the 
financial statement or the balance sheet.  
There are also so -called anti-patterns  which must be avoided in the cloud by all means:  
Entity -services  are services that expose the service’s domain directly on the API as simple CRUD 
(create, read, update, delete) services as made popular by Spring Boot and other frameworks . This 
inevitably  results in an architecture where the  business function has to reside in some “higher -level” 
microservice that orchestrates and manipulates these entity services from the outside. This is 
problematic for multiple reasons: (1) It couples the business function service to the availability of the  
entity services , leading to a compound availability of the business function that is worse than the 
availability of the single entity services. (2) It couples the business function services semantically to 
the entity services. As a consequence, a change t o the entity service results in incompatible and 
disruptive changes to all its consumers so that the business functions have to be redeployed upon 
©2020 SAP SE – Internal    43 
  
 
SAP’s North Star Architecture  changes of the entity services. This contradicts the idea of evolutionary architecture and becomes 
unresolvab le with many entity services consumed by many business processes. (3) Many business 
function services will start reusing entity services which results in a high workload for the entity 
services. This puts a strong availability and performance penalty on th e entity service and contradicts 
availability . (4) Consistency is virtually impossible to achieve across services.  
Simply put, entity services end up having the same issues that we typically find in monolithic 
applications plus inherit all the issues of d istributed systems. Thus, they must be avoided whenever 
possible. To avoid entity services, we strongly propose to design systems after the service by 
lifecycle  and hexagonal architecture  patterns and keep the evolvability  goal in mind for every 
design dec ision.  
Development Frameworks and Languages  
We need to identify a set of foundational components that foster reuse and a good developer 
experience. As cloud native developers and business application developers both need to assemble 
their microservices from smaller components, we need to foster a constant exchange on application 
design , and our internal services and libraries need to equally address both personas’ needs.  
In terms of application frameworks and languages, happy paths will eme rge around popular 
frameworks. The approach is to leverage open source frameworks as much as possible and fill in any 
gaps identified in those frameworks (contributed back to the open source project) or build add -ons 
to SAP -relevant open source solutions.  
Building applications on open source foundations and adding the SAP -specific deltas on top will allow 
LoB teams to get started immediately, knowing that the investments they have made today will still 
be valuable in the future. Developers also benefit from  the broad knowledge available in the 
respective communities.  
Libraries that enable the interoperability with SAP software and services are key open source 
contributions. For example, the CAP framework provides extensions to the open source Spring Boot 
framework for building services with OData and SAP HANA. Extending the most popular languages 
and frameworks with streamlined access to our services will increase adoption and speed of 
development. This means, we should strive to provide a streamlined consump tion through client 
libraries or side -car approaches (like in Microsoft Dapr ) for our SAP services that will then integrate 
with the leading open source frameworks.  
Especially, fundamental services like the  event bus or the audit log need to be integrated into 
popular open source frameworks and provide clean and open APIs. For languages and frameworks 
that we do not provide integrations for, there is still the option to consume the services by providing 
own client implementations based on well -documented, clean APIs published in SAP API Business 
Hub.  
LoB application teams combine the foundation libraries into working business services and 
applications. By doing so, they will – over time – create the necessary  abstraction layers and 
learnings that can then be consolidated into a platform in the years to follow. Based on that 
foundation, more abstract and low -code layers can be developed, making sure that application 
development will become faster and accessible  for business experts (in contrast to technical 
experts).  
Observing our current usage, the following frameworks SHOULD be used by default as a starting 
point: Spring Boot, NodeJS, and ABAP/RAP. Particularly Spring Boot has a vast existing ecosystem for 
enterprise application development and a broad and active community that we should tap into. 
Note, that this does not exclude other open source tools and frameworks but intends to make sure 
©2020 SAP SE – Internal    44 
  
 
SAP’s North Star Architecture  that the three mentioned ones are integrated in the best possible way . The same applies for 
languages: For Java, JavaScript/NodeJS and ABAP we expect to have a high level of tool support (e.g. , 
streamlined, compliant pipelines with code scanning).  
 Developers MAY also use other languages, but they then MUST ensure compliance with 
applicable SAP standards. The set of primary frameworks and languages is expected to 
change over time.  
Based on these basic language and framework constraints, different usage patterns of the 
frameworks are still possible as the frameworks  still give a high degree of freedom. Here, best 
practices will emerge over time. By sharing experiences in the community, and by providing 
boilerplate projects, example projects , and education material, a library of “templates” for service 
and application  developments can be provided.  
 
 
Out of the large solution space at hand, we need to identify a limited number of blueprints over time 
that capture the best -working approaches as patterns, boilerplate code, example projects , etc. to 
make development s repe atable  that use any given approach. In order to reach this goal, additional 
conceptual work is needed in the upcoming North Star timeframe. Ideally, we will reach a 
significantly clearer  state within the next year.

SAP’s North Star Architecture  Infrastructure and Multi -Cloud Strategy  
This chapter discusses our data centers and infrastructure strategy.  
Guidance Summary:  
• Decision s about hyperscaler and location depend on a product’s business case 
and have to be made case by case . 
• Automate deployment of Kernel services to multiple regions and hyperscalers.  
• Proprietary hyperscaler services may be used after lock -in effects and private 
cloud deployment issues have been assessed.  
• “Regional Hubs” concept  needs to be adhered to when planning deployment 
locations.  
• Deliver hyperscaler -like IaaS and PaaS functionality to all SAP data centers using 
“PlusOne” stack (VMWare) as well as Gardener on Metal ( → sunset heritage 
platforms like GMP).  
• Provide a global SAP CDN infrastructure, providing caching, web application 
firewa lling, and DDoS protection as a component of the One Platform.  
 
 
 
Multi -Cloud Strategy  
SAP's multi -cloud strategy is well known and is based on two important fundamental principles:  
 1. No-compete : SAP MUST NOT compete with hyperscalers on infrastructure and 
commodity services; on the contrary, SAP leverages  hyperscalers worldwide by moving 
more and more of its cloud -based services to hyperscaler datacenters.  
2. Flexibility : SAP SHOULD provide hyperscaler choice and flexibility , both for the 
deployment of its own services and applications, and for those of its partners and 
customers. It is important for SAP to maintain a good relationship with all hyperscalers.  
Currently, w e have thousands of customers running productive applications in our own data centers  
(SAP DC) , based on the Neo runtime. Several SAP applications (SuccessFactors, for instance) run 
primarily in SAP -operated data centers as well. SAP DC remains an importan t pillar of our 
infrastructure strategy, but it becomes clear that the current heterogeneous set of data center 
hardware and software “stacks” (Converged Cloud, GMP, etc.) needs consolidation.  
 
 
Strategic Coverage Planning on Service/Application Level  
SAP's multi -cloud strategy does not  mandate a “one -size-fits-all” guidance. For example, we explicitly 
do not require that “every service/application needs to run on every hyperscaler”. The choice is 
made per service or application, according to LoB needs.  
Enabling a service or application on multiple hyperscalers and environments has a cost. Developers 
need to choose from self -run services, SAP services, and provider -specific services and must create 
interfaces to these. Being aware of these implications and costs, teams need to plan their own 

©2020 SAP SE – Internal    46 
  
 
SAP’s North Star Architecture  approach, driven by business requirements, current obligations, and expected future needs. A 
thorough analysis should be conducted up-front , as these decisions have long -lasting impact.  
Business considerations play a dominant role – for instance, support for a private -cloud -based 
offering or to allow customers the choice of cloud provider or geographic location. Regional 
coverage is related to legal and other compliance regulations  – for example,  the need for data 
locality. LoBs need to consider local jurisdiction requirements (e.g., GDPR, Russian data laws) as well 
as contractual obligations (like EU Access). If a service consumer needs to provide EU Access 
compliance and has a hard dependency on a dependent service, that service must also be EU Access 
compliant.  
 If the necessary prerequisites are not met, the consuming LoB MUST negotiate with the 
providers of dependent services in the entire dependency chain to reach agreement or plan 
for capab ility degradation.  
Deploying on additional cloud providers and in additional regions adds to an application’s complexity 
and data transfer costs, albeit, depending on the business scenario, this is may not be a primary 
concern. Not every application needs to run in every region or on every hyperscaler, but there are 
valid cases for which this portability is needed or desirable.  
The ability of applications to deploy their services on SAP CP or directly on one or multiple 
hyperscalers requir es the cross -platform availability of essential backing services to support them. 
Foremost the Kernel Services, but also the many other "reuse" services , built by application or 
platform teams , need to deliver on the promise to be “always there”. This mean s that they are 
available within all jurisdictions and regions, reachable via APIs from any hyperscaler. Therefore, 
these backing services MUST  be designed and built as globally distributed and scalable systems.  
Kernel Service Availability  
 Deploying a se rvice or application into an additional region MUST be an automated and 
standardized process with as little variance as possible across the different deployments. All 
features and respective underlying services – especially Kernel Services – SHOULD be 
available for all customers globally, unless local restrictions make this economically or 
technically unfeasible. Our general approach is that customized variants of our services 
SHOULD be avoided whenever possible.  
Hyperscaler -native PaaS Services  
Hyperscale rs continue to invest, expand to complete development platforms, and continuously 
enhance their offerings with new innovative services with a high ability to execute and innovate. SAP 
can benefit from these innovations by using native hyperscaler services,  and we encourage teams to 
actively explore the possibility of external services.  
SAP's multi -cloud strategy should not be understood as a requirement to be able to run each SAP 
application/service on each and every hyperscaler in every region. This would lead to a need for a 
globally available abstraction layer between the applications and the hyperscalers, hiding 
“everything” provider -specific. Not only would it introduce an unsolvable platform task to build a 
fully generic yet flexible cross -platform abs traction that provides the same breadth of functionality 
as the underlying providers’ capabilities, it would also represent a limiting factor for building 
solutions that fit customers’ use cases.  
Individual applications need to know their customers, their use cases, and the legal and contractual 
terms under which SAP provides its services. Some applications may decide to offer their service via 
one hyperscaler only. If this can be asserted with certainty – also going forward – the usage of native 

©2020 SAP SE – Internal    47 
  
 
SAP’s North Star Architecture  hyperscaler services would not only be advisable but also economically reasonable, as there can be 
gains achieved by following the well -documented and well -understood hyperscalers’ native designs 
for TCO, TCD, and time to market.  
On the other hand, many solutions cannot rely on a single hyperscaler – for example, applications 
that have a truly global reach that cannot be covered by one hyperscaler alone – as some markets do 
not have the required hyperscaler coverage from one vendor. Customer contract s may make it 
necessary to provide the services on multiple hyperscalers, or a product strategy may aim for a 
private cloud offering.  
Even a few existing obligations can already have significant impact on an application’s or service’s

guarantee data residency and access by operations and support personnel within the European 
Economic Area (EEA).  
 Such guarantees  MUST be ensured across the entire transitive dependency chain from the 
application via all intermediate services to the infrastructure. Hyperscalers offer only a 
limited selection13 of their services under these conditions, which may outright prevent the 
use of other native services for su ch customers. This raises the question

necessary to provide the services on multiple hyperscalers, or a product strategy may aim for a

Even a few existing obligations can already have significant impact on an application’s or service’s 
selection of native services. “EU Access” legally obliges SAP, if committed to a customer, to 
guarantee data residency and access by operations and support personnel within the European 
Economic Area (EEA).  
 Such guarantees  MUST be ensured across the entire transitive dependency chain from the 
application via all intermediate services to the infrastructure. Hyperscalers offer only a 
limited selection13 of their services under these conditions, which may outright prevent the 
use of other native services for su ch customers. This raises the question whether native 
services shall be completely avoided from the beginning or only substituted for those 
customers that cannot use them.  
These challenges are mostly applicable to the larger existing LoB applications and t o 
platform offerings that, by their nature, need to provide broad coverage, such as Kernel 
Services. In these cases, the usage of native services MUST be carefully planned by the 
application and appropriate substitution strategies MUST be defined.  
The North Star Architecture aims to provide more guidance for these cases in the future. There are 
multiple possible building blocks here, such as the use of open source software (e.g., PostgreSQL) or 
SAP components (SAP HANA), open protocols or abstraction layer s (e.g., for Object Storage), which 
need to be understood in detail in the course of the North Star Architecture work. As a general 
strategy, we encourage the conservative use of native services for the core offering of a solution, 
focusing mostly on infra structure and selected PaaS services, ideally using open standards that 
would leave open the opportunity to port to alternatives in the future.  
Consuming hyperscaler services is not always about having multiple services in the same 
“equivalence class” that  needs to be substitutable across hyperscalers – e.g., substituting a managed 
PostgreSQL service. We also want to stress that applications could even use services from multiple 
hyperscalers in a “best -of-breed” pick and choose approach. Some services are h yperscaler -specific, 
and it does not make sense to provide an abstraction for them. For example, native security services 
are probably preferred over a third -party solution that covers all hyperscalers. For those cases, a 
service or application may need to  adopt each hyperscaler’s proprietary solution – or, going forward, 
we identify methods to orchestrate or abstract these services based on identified patterns and 
practices.  
 Generally, the use of native hyperscaler services (or SAP services) MUST be driv en primarily 
by market requirements and by functional and non -functional features, TCO considerations, 
and availability fitting the applications’ roadmap. But also – according to the leadership’s 
decision – the use of hyperscaler services in production wor kloads competing with key and 
strategic SAP technologies will be governed by a “no -go” list in a to -be-published guideline.

SAP’s North Star Architecture  In summary:  Hyperscaler services can be used in production, as long as they comply with the North 
Star Architecture guidance, are not on the “no -go” list, and do not impede compliance with any SAP 
product standards, applicable laws, customer obligations, or the appli cations’ own guidelines and 
rules.  
Hyperscaler Lock -in Risks  
While we provide the freedom and flexibility to use hyperscaler offerings, the ESLT has decided to 
balance the advantages of using hyperscalers with a defendable approach for managing risk. As we  
take on more responsibility in running our customers’ most essential business systems, we must not 
underestimate our dependency on vendors to render our services. This includes concepts such as 
planning for portability, backup, and disaster recovery proce dures that should be in place as a 
contingency for all services and applications as a precautionary measure to enable the continuity of 
service in case a hyperscaler becomes unavailable – a case with low probability but high impact.  
SAP-owned Cloud Infrast ructure  
As described in chapter “Runtime Environments , Containers , and Kubernetes ” all platforms and 
applications must run on Kubernetes. Further, private cloud must be  based on Gardener. 
Consequently, virtual machines will only be consumed by Gardener (to deploy Kubernetes nodes) 
and legacy applications. The infrastructure deployed in SAP ’s data centers must be optimized to 
serve Kubernetes nodes.  
For a next generation of SAP ’s data centers, we must shift our approach from an enterprise -centric 
approach to a hyperscaler -like approach, putting economies of scale at the heart of a cost -effective 
model. One consideration is that SAP must not rely on a single vendor for any part of the stack that is 
serving SAP products. A minimum of three vendors MUST be available to prevent SAP to be 
dependent on a single vendor – e.g., network switches can be purchased from Cisco, Arista, or 
Mellanox. If there are  less than three vendors o n the market that can serve an infrastructure 
component, SAP has to own this component – for example, SAP has developed Gardener and does 
not use OpenShift to be independent of RedHat. This independence is strategic for SAP’s 
sustainability and success. Th us, SAP should in the long  run not exclusively rely on VMware as the 
single vendor for data center management and virtualization. As there is a lack of alternatives on the 
market, SAP is invest ing in bringing Gardener on bare metal. Gardener on  Metal is developed as 
open source in collaboration with SAP partners (i. e. Deutsche Telekom, ATOS, Finanz -Informatik 
Technologie Service). The approach of Kubernetes on bare metal has been proven in producti on and 
is not novel in itself. SAP can self -certify products and hardware for Gardener on Metal, which results 
in a wider and less expensive range of compatible hardware. Open source components are favored 
over proprietary components – for example, the Azure SONiC operating system  is used on network 
switches instead of an expensive proprietary OS from Cisco or Arista. Gardener on Metal reduces 
complexity of the infrastructure stack, resulting in higher availabi lity and reduced operations 
expenses. Consequently, every investment in proprietary infrastructure components instead of 
Gardener on  Metal must be thoroughly argued.  
Edge Services and Connectivity  
A global backbone connecting multiple cloud regions is cruc ial for high -performing and reliable cloud 
services. Therefore, GCS is deploying a next generation backbone for SAP, providing Layer -2 and 
Layer -3 IPv4 and IPv6 connectivity. Today, SAP’s internet connectivity is handled separately at every 
location. The n ew backbone allows to build a more hyperscaler -like way to connect SAP’s locations: 
Around the globe, at locations where multiple glass fibers meet – Edge -PoPs (Point -of-Presence) are 
established. Those Edge -PoPs are connected to IP transit providers and l ocal Internet Exchanges (IX). 
Via the SAP Backbone they are connected to the SAP cloud regions (DE, US -East, US -West, etc.). 
©2020 SAP SE – Internal    49 
  
 
SAP’s North Star Architecture  Internet traffic targeted toward SAP DCs enters the global SAP network near to the customer and will 
be transferred over the SAP Ba ckbone to the cloud region. On the way back the traffic will flow from 
the cloud region to the customer’s nearest Edge -PoP and exit the SAP Backbone there. This allows to 
ensure high performance and resiliency of SAP’s internet connectivity. Customers can also directly 
peer with SAP at the Edge -PoPs. Mostly, an Edge -PoP is a single rack in a colocation space near IP 
transit providers.  
Apart from connectivity the Edge -PoPs can provide additional services:  
• DNS  
SAP will establish a global DNS service. By prov iding DNS at the edge, customers’ DNS 
requests will be handled with minimal latency. Inherent to the distributed system is a 
horizontal scalability of the system. Using Anycast IP addresses, the SAP DNS will be available 
globally using the same IP address and every request goes to the nearest Edge -PoP. DNS will 
be integrated into Gardener and can be configured by the deployment pipeline and an 
application itself using Kubernetes custom resource definitions . The SAP DNS service MUST 
support a simple process to request subdomains for SAP -managed domains, such as 
ondemand.com or the .sap TLD.  
• Content Delivery Network (CDN) and Caching  
The edge nodes will function as a CDN service similar to Cloudflare and Akamai. Static 
content will be cached at the edge and de livered from there to the customer. This reduces 
latency as well as load on the application deployed in an SAP cloud region. Dynamic content 
can be cached as specified by the application using HTTP headers.  
• Web Application Firewall (WAF)  
In addition to CDN  functionality, a WAF can be used. Access to endpoints will be filtered at 
the edge, protecting the backend service.  
• DDoS Protection  
As the Edge -PoPs are located all around the globe, DDoS attacks will always hit the attacking 
node’s next Edge -PoP. This wa y a DDoS traffic will be “load balanced” over all Edge -PoPs, 
allowing every Edge -PoP to handle and mitigate a fraction of the DDoS traffic. This is how 
state of the art DDoS mitigation is done by Cloudflare and Akamai. All SAP products MUST 
use a globally distributed DDoS mitigation service – be it Akamai, Cloudflare, AWS 
CloudFront, GCP Armor, or the described Gardener CDN with DDoS protection. Proprietary 
DDoS mitigation appliance s (e.g., from Radware or Arbor) as currently installed in SAP data 
centers ARE NOT sufficient to mitigate DDoS attacks and MUST NOT BE USED as the only 
DDoS protection . Those  appliances reduce the service’s responsiveness and are not able to 
mitigate very large attacks. A service that is under attack and not protected by a global 
mitigation network, will be blackholed to protect the rest of SAP’s infrastructure.  
• TLS Termination  
The Edge -PoPs have to decrypt the HTTPS traffic to provide the described services. Also, 
Akamai and Cloudflare decrypt the traffic on the edge and do comput ations based on the 
content (e.g., TCP/IP packets and HTTP headers). By installing an SAP -owned edge 
infrastructure, we can remove the “man  in the middle ”; no other company can access the 
decrypted personal data of our customers.  
Certificate Management  
TLS SHOULD  always be used. For internal service -to-service communication, a service mesh shall 
govern the provision of certificates, based on an internal CA infrastructure. External -facing standard 
TLS certificates SHOULD by default be acquired by Let’s Encrypt  using the ACME protocol. Automatic 
renewal MUST be integrated into application operations.  
©2020 SAP SE – Internal    50 
  
 
SAP’s North Star Architecture  For Extended Validation Certificates ("green labeled certificates”) – or where there is a need for a 
certificate issued to a specific name – SAP’s standard source today is Digicert. The Digicert account is 
managed by GCS. GCS will provide an API that allows developers to request and renew their 
certificates programmatically. Automatic renewal MUST be inte grated into application operations.  
Cloud and On -Premise, Private Cloud  
Our huge existing on -premise customer base may or may not migrate to the cloud over time. SAP 
must support hybrid scenarios in which cloud solutions need to integrate seamlessly with o n-
premise solutions. Hybrid scenarios introduce new architectural challenges: How do the systems 
connect? How do they exchange data effectively and securely? How do user contexts propagate 
between systems? These and other  questions need to be answered and are best approached by 
concrete integration scenarios that provide immediate business value.  
Private cloud is a case -by-case consideration of actual business value. While SAP Cloud Platform is 
private -cloud -ready, preparing other software for private clou d deployments can be costly. For 
example, hyperscaler services might be out of scope, or may need to be substituted for available 
solutions in the private cloud. The abstraction layer discussion in multi -cloud scenarios (see “ Multi -
Cloud Strategy ”) applies here as well.  
 Private cloud requirements  MUST be considered early on, as they deeply impact the 
architecture and design. Private cloud should be an exception, only c onsidered when there 
is considerable business value, at a high customer price tag. Therefore, the North Star 
Architecture does not address private cloud topics beyond the generic discussion of multi -
cloud, portability, and abstraction.  
As long as containe rized (Kubernetes native) applications are running in public clouds, it is 
straightforward to ensure their management objectives (SLAs, Backup, RPO, etc.): all lifecycle 
management operations can be timely executed using APIs that are directly and publicly  reachable. 
In on -premise private cloud deployments, the situation is quite different because we do not expect 
the customers to grant SAP (or its partners) full access to the infrastructure in their data center – 
even if VPN setups were feasible.  
For the support of Kubernetes -enabled , isolated , on-premise private clouds, we propose that SAP 
applications/products converge their lifecycle management tooling using the following cloud native 
mechanisms:  
1. A special -purpose controller – a so-called operator – must  be shipped alongside the product. 
This local operator manifests the human administrative knowledge regarding the product and 
the different containers comprising it. Instead of various administrative scripts for the 
product administrator to handle manually, the operator contains all necessary m anagement 
tasks as code  – such as zero -downtime, rolling upgrades, anomaly detection, and failure -
mitigation. Shipped together with the product, the operator ensures that it can be used with 
minimal human intervention, again reducing the marginal cost of o perations. Operators can 
be transported within containers and can be activated in new Kubernetes environments in 
which they establish a purpose -specific subsystem API.  
2. These SAP -specific, programmatic local operators should be equipped with “call back hom e” 
capabilities and connect to their respective

SAP’s North Star Architecture  Data Management and Analytics  
Data is the key to  success of any business. This chapter discusses our strategy for data management  
and analytics, and the implementation of  the SAP One Domain Model as previously explained in “SAP 
One Domain Model ”. 
With the world’s  largest spectrum of business applications, SAP is uniquely positioned to help our 
customers leverage data to run their businesses better. To capitalize on this opportunity, we must 
provide access to consistent and semantically rich data across application s and business processes.  
Our goal is for SAP to be widely considered the leading enabler of data -driven business innovation in 
the cloud.  
The North Star Architecture  recognizes and addresses the needs of two distinct target groups:  
• Our customers and part ners who need simple access to data, available across the range of 
SAP applications, with a common set of data semantics  – making it easy to build extensions, 
applications, and to derive insight.  
• Our own product teams who need to leverage data  for the enha ncement of our products 
with intelligent features.  
 
Guidance Summary:  
• Only managed data services are used going forward . 
• HANA Cloud MUST be used for structured business data . 
• Adoption of ODM (integration, APIs, ML, analytics, etc.)  is mandatory.  
• Applications MUST adopt SAC to provide in -app embedded analytics capabilities .  
• Applications MUST provide analytical content . 
• ODM exposure with APIs is mandatory.  
• Develop and adopt data -lake-based services for search, analytics, and machine 
learning .

• TG32 - Application Analytics  
• TG15 - Cent ral Search  
 
 
  

©2020 SAP SE – Internal    53 
  
 
SAP’s North Star Architecture   
Our current application landscape consists of a set of applications that were developed 
independently of each other, on separate technology stacks a nd data models, and with a variet y of 
approaches to exposing and sharing data externally. This makes it complex and time -consuming for 
SAP, partners , and customers  to implement analytics and end -to-end processes that leverage data 
from multiple applications.  
As we work to define the North  Star Architecture  for data and analytics, we intend to solve the 
following challenges:  
• Lack of a common data model and data alignment  
• Lack of a consistent way to access data across applications  
• Locality of data across multiple hyperscalers and regions  
• Need for a consistent approach to eventing  
• Need for data governance primitives  
• Lack of  a single -model data representation  
• Need for a consistent approach to data authorization  
 
 
Traditionally, 80% of the effort to get insight from data goes into collecting  and aligning the data. The 
complexity of data extraction, transformation, and enrichment must be hidden from customer s. Our 
vision is to define an SAP data platform, that enables easy access to data from all products to deliver 
the promise of data -driven int elligent cloud applications .  
The data management vision cannot stop at the data access layer. All of SAP’s applications share a 
common set of challenges around technology, security, scalability, quality, integration , and cost. 
Modern cloud design principl es lead to an ever -increasing number of distributed applications and 
self-contained microservices. This is necessary to achieve a high level of cloud qualities, such as 
performance, cost -efficiency, scalability , and availability , which results in applications that are more 
agile and easier to manage. The trade -off is that it also results in a much higher integration 
complexity, which we must counterbalance  with a clear data architecture that minimizes data 
replication and transfor mation.  
The North Star Architecture  drives toward essential cloud qualities, including a competitive TCO, a 
hands -off operational model with high availability, elastic scaling to 1  billion  users, and costs that 
scale with consumption, including near -zero marginal cost for new tenants. We will aim to minimize 
duplicated effort by defining a reference technology stack.  
To do this, we will develop a set of data -driven principles supported by enabling tools, technology , 
and services, that can be applied acros s all functions for how we provide, integrate, derive , and 
analyze  data to enhance the  value  for the customer.  This needs to be an iterative approach that will 
provide incremental value and create a "muscle" within all SAP areas. The intent is not to be 
prescriptive, but to be useful to application engineers in helping them achieve their goals, and to 
provide guardrails that steer us toward convergence.  
The Data Management and Analytics workstream provide s guidance in the form of best practices 
and blueprin ts to SAP product owners, architects, designers , and engineers. With a focus on the data 
management and analytics layer, this will lead to data that is more accessible and consumable across 
our range of products, as well as to greater efficiency in develop ing and operating our cloud services.  

©2020 SAP SE – Internal    54 
  
 
SAP’s North Star Architecture  Data Model  
• Guid ance : Adoption of ODM (integration, APIs, ML, analytics, etc.) is mandatory.  
• Guid ance : ODM exposure with APIs is mandatory.  
A common data model is critical for support ing end-to-end processes, an alytics , and intelligence that 
combines data from different applications. The work on data model alignment and adoption of the 
SAP One Data Model (ODM)  will be a foundational element to unlocking the true value of data across 
the s uite.  All application APIs tha t expose or consume data will comply with TG23 , whereby all data 
available via external APIs will be consistent with the SAP One Data Model .  
Applications will also need to expose, via APIs, semantically rich business content in support of 
analytics – going beyond the core data covered by ODM. This will require them to share metadata 
that allows rich analytics to be built outside the traditional boundaries of a single application.   
Data Management as a Service   
• Guid ance : only managed data services MUST be used going forward.  
Separation of concerns and distribution of work into autonomous service units is the key idea in a 
service -oriented approach. We will also apply this approach to data management to reduce the 
operati onal burden for individual applications. Data management technologies will mainly be 
consumed by applications as managed  services  in the future. It is inefficient for each application or 
service to deploy and manage its own database technology. One main tr ansition in this regard is 
from locally  operated HANA (on -premise)  instances , data warehousing, and data management tools 
to managed HANA Cloud Services.  
Data Management Technology  
• Guid ance : SAP HANA Cloud MUST be used for structured business data . 
Prevale nt paradigms used to build business applications are changing towards cloud architectures, 
which eventually also disrupts existing concepts of data management. Applications strive for 
decomposing themselves into self -contained independent services to achie ve cloud qualities like 
cost-efficiency and scalability. Data assets are increasingly distributed. Best practices will be defined 
for implementing data persistence for microservices. Good design dictates independent stores for 
each microservice, horizontal  scalability, and other factors. In consequence, changing data 
architectures need to be safeguarded by a strong HANA data platform that will implement additional 
cloud qualities  including  elasticity, high availability, and cost efficiency  to achieve the needed 
acceptance by applications.   
At the macro level, the North Star Architecture  relies on well -defined REST APIs for access to all data 
from individual services, as well as driving toward event sourcing to expose state changes and shar e 
data.  
At the micro level, when choosing the optimal data management technology for a particular service, 
HANA Cloud must be used by all new applications/services whe never structured business data is 
stored and managed. To support this direction, HANA Cl oud is evolving to become a true a cloud  
native service, implementing a data pyramid with fast in -memory processing at the top and down to 
SQL-on-files for cloud -scale object store data. Through its Data Fabric technology, HANA Cloud will 
address geographi cally distributed data and become the backbone of the SAP data plane.

SAP’s North Star Architecture  In other cases, where a different type of data  management capability is needed,  consideration 
should be given to:  
• Optimal data model  
• Transactional, analytical , and search capabilities needed  
• Horizontal scalability  
• Costs for development and ownership  
• Availability within the targeted hyperscaler  
• Potential future cost of lock -in to a highly proprietary hyperscaler or third -party technology  
• Availability of suitable Data Processing Agreement s with the service provider  
Data Lake  
• Guid ance : We SHOULD d evelop and adopt data -lake-based services for search, analytics, 
machine learning . 
SAP has extraordinary domain knowledge  with a  holistic and consistent view as well as the semantic 
richness of pre -integrated data across multiple services and business processes. The move toward 
microservices could result in greater difficulty deriving insight from data across the suite. This, and 
the trend  of increased  data collection  for application intelligence , leads to the need for a consistent 
business -wide data lake strategy. The SAP Data Lake , an always -on logical singleton, is one of the 
technical building blocks of the SAP data plane, toget her with the event log, modeling service, etc. It  
will enable new business models  by enabling  deeper insights from existing data  and support cross -
application  analytics via the SAP Data Warehouse Cloud . By providing a single access plane , spanning 
data fro m all SAP applications, across hyperscalers and regions, we will not only simplify data access 
and integration but provide the fuel for a new generation of intelligent applications . 
Application s will be expected to expose application events  (such as “Emplo yee Hired” event) , data 
events (“Employee changed” event) and usage  events ( as in “User clicked button ‘Hire Employee’ in 
the Web UI” ) in the SAP Data Lake wherever  practical and economical . Guidelines are being 
developed in the Data Architecture (TG20) workstream , towards an event sourcing approach for data 
sharing and collection, moving away from relying on database -level replication technologies. An 
architecture paper laying out the direct ion and plans for the SAP Data Lake is in progress.  
Analytics  
• Guid ance : Applications MUST adopt SAC to provide in -app embedded analytics capabilities .  
• Guid ance : Applications MUST provide analytical content.  
We are already well along the path of applications adopting SAC for embedded analytics within the 
context of a single application. However, t here is still significant work to be done to enable cross -
product analytics . Our goal is to enable customers to mov e seamlessly  between embedded analytics 
and enterprise analytics. Cross -product analytics will be enabled by SAP Data Warehouse Cloud 
(DWC) and the SAP Data Lake, combining and aligning data from the relevant applications. SAP 
Analytics Cloud (SAC) provide s the consumption layer, while the underlying SAP DWC capabilities  
enable powerful data modeling, especially for cross -application and complex scenarios. To enable 
cross -product analytics and intelligence, it is essential that all applications expose relevant data via 
APIs  such that the data can be easily accessed via SAC and Data Warehou se Cloud. Additional 
guidance will be developed for the integration scenarios to be used between the applications and 
Data Warehouse Cloud  – both in the short term and  longer term as the SAP Data Lake strategy takes 
shape .
