SAP’s North Star Architecture  Integrated Intellige nt Suite  Foundations  
This chapter discusses the challenges SAP faces in forming a well -integrated suite  out of our different 
business applications by creating integrated consisten cy across all of them. Topics discussed are API 
strategy and the role of the new SAP Cloud Platform Kernel Services in forging coherency and 
alignment  across the suite. Other topics, such as shared  security and APIs for developers , are 
covered in other cha pters.  
Guidance Summary:  
• Well -documented, public APIs MUST be available (e.g., TG03). 
• APIs MUST be published in API Hub (TG03, TG27, TG39) . 
• CPI MUST  be used for non -SAP to SAP process integration  (TG29) . 
• Make Business Configuration Service mandatory  (TG31 ). 
• Ensure fully automated provisioning and facilitate the integration setup and 
monitoring (TG04, TG11) . 
• LoBs MUST  make  generalized services available via Service Discovery  (TG04, TG06) . 
• MUST  provide standard metrics across services . 
• MUST  adopt Kernel Services and Zones (TG04, TG02) . 
• LoBs MUST use the Business  Event Bus Kernel Service for publishing business events . 
 
 
Learn more:

• TG27 - Business Events  
• TG29 - Mediated Integration

SAP spent roughly $ 70 billion  in the past ten years to acquire great companies like SuccessFactors, 
Concur, Fieldglass, Ariba, Hybris, Gigya, Callidus, and Qualtrics. These LoBs now form the core of the 
intelligent suite portfolio. Yet, they operate relatively independently – with the ir own operations,  
infrastructure and support services, monitoring, technical administration, and underlying platform 
technology stack and programming models. The lack of a common engineering approach results in 
redundant development efforts and solutions developed in isolation as each LoB moves along its 
own cloud native path. More importantly , this affects the quality of our products in terms of 
simplicity, usability, and ease of integration  by customers , significantly raising their  cost of ownership  
(TCO) . 
In addition, customer landscape s may contain non -SAP solutions. To work with this variety of 
solutions, a diverse team of experts in all technologies is required for an implementation project. 

©2020 SAP SE – Internal    57 
  
 
SAP’s North Star Architecture  This may involve product configurations, data model cus tomization across multiple applications 
included in the respective business process, data integration, and side -by-side extensions  – 
complementing the buil t-in customization capabilities of the individual SAP solutions.  
Integration Challenges  
To reduce cu stomers' integration effort , we need better pre-integration of our LoB solutions . We 
consider four types of integration s: 
• (Business) process integration : The most important integration type in the context of SAP's 
Intelligent Enterprise connecting  SAP's so lutions (Concur, S/4, Ariba, etc.) along a business 
process.  
• Functional (application) integration : Many business applications implement common 
business functions  like a task -inbox  or consent management. Using shared  services and 
(open)  standards instead of bespoke  solutions  guarantees operability,  consistent behavior 
and a good customer experience , and reduces  development cost.  
• Data integration : See “Data Management and Analytics ”.  
• UI integration : Consistent user experience like cross -product navigation, one central task -
inbox, etc. You can find details  in section “User Experience ”. 
Each  LoB application has similar challenges  – legal, compliance, integrating with customers’ identity 
systems, commercial/LCM aspects – and therefore needs similar capabilities, such as audit -log, task -
inbox, key -management, consent management, etc. Multiple implementations are expensive and 
often in complete , due to  reasons like :  
• Different technologies:  New trends or acquisitions will introduce new technologies. This 
must be accepted.  
• Different standards/protocols:  Applications with different standards require protocol 
mappings and/or transformations for integration, increasing cost. We should use open 
standards (example CloudEvents) and open source for commodity functionality14. 
• Unaligned data models:  Different data models requires adapters/mappings. The DMA 
program, defining SAP One D omain Model, addresses  this.  
• Tight  service coupling:  Assumptions made by consumers and providers of a service lead to 
greater complexity. Loose coupling will be fostered by microservices and eventing 
approaches.”   
Due to the heterogeneity of applications (like Concur, Ariba, C/4, etc.), customers must  wire point -
to-point applications' tenants with the same operational role (e.g. , "staging") and establish trust by 
exchanging credentials and endpoints. This process is expensive, long, tedious , and error prone. 
Customers are responsible for maintain ing these "wirings" during upgrades and rotate passwords for 
security reasons , etc. This identity integration challenge  is addressed by the "Zones" solution, further 
discussed in “Security and Identity Management ”.

SAP’s North Star Architecture   
Consistent, aligned, and discoverable APIs  
 Applications and services SHOULD communicate through well -defined interfaces in the 
form of APIs (REST, O Data, etc.) and events, preferably in a loosely coupled and 
asynchronous way. All interfaces MUST be centrally documented according to TG03. To 
establish a successful ecosystem of customers and partners, a harmonization of consistent, 
holistic, well -docume nted, and discoverable  APIs is needed. This is important not only for 
customers and partners, but also between SAP teams. For this purpose, services MUST 
describe their APIs using OData EDM, OpenAPI, AsyncAPI, or Protocol Buffers/gRPC (in case 
of binary RPC) . 
Additionally, SAP  applications and services will expose metadata of their interfaces by means of the 
Open Discovery API  to enable an automated discovery of system capabilities. This will enable a 
customer -specific view on events and APIs to complement the generic and stati c view  – for example,  
in the API Business Hub. By implementing the Open Discovery API , metadata of all exposed public 
APIs and events of a system/application shall be discoverabl e for any design time tool in a standard 
manner – by customers, partners, and SAP developers.  
The alignment of business APIs is target of TG03 - Aligned Business APIs (and Open Discovery). As a 
developer you can start to implement the Open Discovery SPI (Service Provider Interface) described 
in TG requirement TG03.R3 (WIP).  
 Also, for domain obje cts that are part of the One Domain Model, the external exposure MUST 
be based on the ODM object definition.  
Remark : Do not mix up API discovery with Service Discovery and Management , which is th e related 
lifecycle topic to address that services need to be discoverable via a service catalog  and enable an 
automated provisioning  as described in “

Consolidated External -Facing Experience  
Especially  in the channels towards our users, we currently s ee a lot of fragmentation, with user -
facing applications and domains being created in each application. We should evaluate and define 
the desired target state for having clear user -facing channels for desktop, web,  mobile web, native 
mobile, chat, voice, e tc. Ideally, all SAP users  will be able to access our solution through a 
cornerstone channel as an entry point, from which there is a natural navigation to other capabilities 
within this channel or even in other apps. Also, APIs towards the outside world a re often strongly 
influenced by historic decisions made in the respective LoBs. By harmonizing the public APIs and 
event streams, we can make it much easier for internal and external developers to tap into our 
solution and build extensions.  
Cloud Platform Integration Technology  
For integrations that span outside of the scope of the intelligent suite, SAP offers the Cloud Platform 
Integration Suite, which focuses on custom integrations with external applications, non -aligned 
applications, and legacy or B2B i ntegration. Its adoption for such use cases is mandated in TG29. To 
enable the us e of this technology, applications must provide respective iFlow content. More details 
can be found in the Cloud Platform North Star Paper . 
Kernel Services15 
To achieve a consistent experience across our solutions, it is necessary to define a minimal set of 
common basic services as mandatory. These are the Kernel Services . The main criteria for defining a 
service as Kernel  Service is , whether it is crucial to h ave all SAP solutions use it to achieve out -of-the-
box integration and suite -quality customer experience. The list is short and carefully selected , since  it 
is not easy to convince all  LoBs to adopt services they did not design and tailor to their need.  
Kernel Services are provided in a variety of areas, like S ecurity and Identity , Application Lifecycle 
Management  (see section  “Operation al Excellence  and Lifecycle Management ”), Core Integration , 
and Experience  (see “User Experience ”). They form the technical foundation of the intelligent suite 
and are delivered as centrally provided and managed services, shared across the entire  product 
portfolio. As such, they not only ease application development and deployment, foster integration , 
and reduce complexity and risk, but also help reduce (integration) costs and efforts for SAP, our 
partners , and customers.  
 
Kernel Services Guidance  
Your adaption journey starts with the usage of Kernel Services. For more information , please visit the 
Kernel Service pages . Here , you find detailed information , like data center availability, related TGs, 
costs , and roadmaps for each service (e.g. , for the Landscape Information Service ) as well as 
tutorials. In the community section you can access presentations and recordings  from the 
community sessions.  
Each Kernel Service is a precondition of at least one TG requirement. Thus , search ing for Kernel -
Service -relevant TGs with requirements in the status “ready to adopt ” is the first step of your 
journey , as your application will be required to fulfill these TG requirements  eventually .

SAP’s North Star Architecture  The status  of the different TGs is regularly updated  on the  Technology Guidelines pages  (just click on 
the link and select Suite Qualities Wave 1 , Suite Qualities 2 or Backlog ). In particular, the core 
integration TGs are a lready included in the new " Integration " product standard.  
There is already an example application to validate the current implementations of Kernel Service s 
and the  zone concept. The KLACKS application  provided by the Cloud Enablement Team is available 
on GitHub. It provides a perfect entry  point for your Kernel Service s journey  and shows  what  is 
possible today and what  is still missing, sometimes also what must be adapted.  
Master Data Integra tion 
Support for the MDI service (see TG22) is mandatory for all applications/services that exchange 
(expose/consume) master data. This allows master data to be synchronized across services. The MDI 
Kernel Service provides the infrastructure to exchange OD M change events across applications. This 
means that, even though the ODM entities are owned by the respective intelligent suite applications, 
applications propagate ODM object changes to MDI. Interested parties can subscribe to th ese events 
and update the ir internal data models accordingly. All intelligent suite applications must integrate 
with MDI to be able to deliver the end -to-end processes for the Intelligent Enterprise and to avoid 
additional mappings. Following this objective, the MDI should subsume  or replace existing master 
data services in the long run. In addition to data change events via MDI, ODM will also define aligned 
“Business Events” that carry business semantics related to the aligned data model. Such events are 
raised by the participatin g applications and are distributed globally through the “Business Event Bus” 
Kernel Service.  
Integration Monitoring  
The increased need to exchange master and transactional data between the different involved cloud 
services and on -premise systems can lead t o exceptions or performance -related issues. The goal of 
Integration Monitoring is to bring transparency in to the data exchange processes, providing a 
common look -and-feel as well as handling independently whether we are dealing with peer -to-peer 
interfaces  or orchestration platforms. See TG11 for more details.  
Zones Concept  
Application tenants are integrated in a context of an operational role  (e.g. , a customer’s production 
environment). A process  in one application's tenant may need to communicate with an other in 
another application within the same operational role , requiring the establishment  of mutual trust . 
Due to the lack of shared tenant concepts, customers struggle with  "wiring" their different tenants 
together.  
This is addressed by the Zones  concept. A zone is a grouping of tenants with a common operational 
role from different solutions. For example: a zone called "Acme -staging" might group Acme's 
SuccessFactors staging  tenant, Acme's S/4HANA staging system, etc. Zones are lightweight metadata, 
basically just identifiers, which are created and managed by customers. Customers can create zones  
(even spanning different  data centers)  as they see fit.

environment). A process  in one application's tenant may need to communicate with an other in 
another application within the same operational role , requiring the establishment  of mutual trust . 
Due to the lack of shared tenant concepts, customers struggle with  "wiring" their different tenants 
together.  
This is addressed by the Zones  concept. A zone is a grouping of tenants with a common operational 
role from different solutions. For example: a zone called "Acme -staging" might group Acme's 
SuccessFactors staging  tenant, Acme's S/4HANA staging system, etc. Zones are lightweight metadata, 
basically just identifiers, which are created and managed by customers. Customers can create zones  
(even spanning different  data centers)  as they see fit.  
Zones are managed by the SAP Cloud Platform Identity Service . This is the central security authority 
that all SAP applications and services trust. As such, the identity service  mediates between any two 
parties who wish to set up trust . It authenticates humans or technical users a nd provides standard -
based digitally signed tokens that allow two parties to securely communicate on behalf of human or 
technical users.  
Tenants in a zone share a common user base, and in fact form the intelligent suite , logically acting as 
one integrated system. We require each application to maintain the map of its local tenants to zones 
©2020 SAP SE – Internal    61 
  
 
SAP’s North Star Architecture  and vice versa. With that, applications can communicate in the correct operational role context 
without involving the customer to wire each and every integration point. W ithin a zone, applications 
trust  each other and can propagate users and expose data securely.  
SAP will involve the customer in the provisioning process of new tenants. Customers will be able to 
initiate the provisioning and select the zone. Applications an d services will receive a request to 
provision a tenant for a customer and the zone to map the new tenant to.  
Customers can consolidate  (merge) two zones into one. This is important for migrating the current 
state (where zones do not exist and where there  is no knowledge of grouping tenants) into the 
target state. Only customer administrators can classify the operational role of their tenant and are 
required to make the grouping and merging decisions. They will start by having each application's 
tenant in a separate zone and evolve as they merge zones up to the day when  all tenants of the 
same operational role are grouped under one zone.  
The orchestration of tenant subscriptions to zones and merging zones is done in the Subscription 
Management Kernel Servic e, which also publishes the mapping to the Cloud Landscape Directory.  
Zones Guidance  
Be prepared ! Zones are to be introduced in mid -2020 and are discussed in TG02  and TG04 . You find a 
lot of information on the Kernel Service pages, under Fundamentals  - Zones . Below is a summary of 
the concepts to be addressed by developers:  
• Integrate with Identity Service  (TG02)  
In this concept, applications/services need to obt ain one service instance of the identity  service. 
This one instance will give the apps/services the credentials to work with IAS for all future 
onboarded tenants.  
• Registering in Subscription Management Service  (TG04)  
A multi -tenant app or service registers  in Subscription Management by providing their identity -
service  instance, and a callback to be called by Subscription Management (onboarding  / 
offboarding and/or  merge zones).  
• Authentication to your application  (TG02)  
Authentication is done in the context of zones. Typically, the application’s URL contains enough 
information for the app to figure  out to which IAS  tenant and zone the request is addressed. 
Then the app will trigger an OAuth2 (or SAML) flow to authenticate the user against the ident ity 
service  tenant of the customer in the context of the requested zone. The result of the 
authentication flow would be an OpenID connect token or SAML Assertion which includes an 
OpenID connect (OIDC) token in it. The OIDC token would include the zone -id (among othe r 
claims , such as user -id) 
• Consuming other zone -enabled services  
When an app/service is integrated with IAS and Subscription Management, it can consume zone -
enabled services. This means, it can create one instance of the service and use its credentials in 
the context of all its tenants. To do so, it needs to report to IAS about this “consumed -api” once, 
and then the two services  – IAS and Subscription management – will make sure that whenever 
the app/service will be onboarded to a zone, so wi ll this dependent service.  
• Offering API consumption (becoming a zone -enabled service  – TG04 ) 
As soon as we reach the target state of the North Star Architecture , we will have established a  
clear API -first approach including life cycle  considerations handled by APIs  (compare paragraph 
Service Management in section “Error! Reference source not found. ”). In addition,  a global  i
dent ity is introduced  SAP-wide . So, as a developer you  would just look -up the APIs on a global 
©2020 SAP SE – Internal    62 
  
 
SAP’s North Star Architecture  service marketplace.  
As of today , we manage these  identities /metering and lifecycle  aspects  with a service broker16. 
Here are the two things  you MUST do:  
 – Implementing a broker  
If your app offers API access, you need to implement a so called Service Broker based 
on the Open Service Broker API . When a service instance is created and bound, your 
Service Bro ker needs to issue credentials to allow access to the service. This is done 
with the help of the IAS instance you own. You may ask IAS to issue credentials for 
you based on your IAS service and potentially based on an input OAuth -client from 
the consumer. These credentials will allow consumers of your API to use IAS to 
obtain an OAuth2 access -token or delegate their OIDC token directly – depending on 
the use case.  
– Registering your service  in Service Management and in Subscription Management  
The service -brok er needs to be registered in the service manager for others to be 
able to instantiate your service. Registering the service in the Subscription 
Management will allow others to define your service as a dependency and get the 
onboarding calls for new zones.  
• Accounting for usage of kernel -services  
Applications and services that use Kernel Services do it in the context of an SAP CP global 
account. The global account represents the paying entity (in SAP teams’ usage, this is a cost 
center), each app/service nee ds (at least) one global account for all its services across the globe. 
Instances of services are created in the region of consumption, and for that the app/service 
need s (at least) one SAP CP Subaccount at each region of consumption. The Subaccount is the  
regional commercial entity in which services are consumed.

SAP’s North Star Architecture  Operation al Excellence  and Lifecycle Management  
 
Note : We use the  terms Lifecycle Management (LM) and Operations (Ops) interchangeably , although  LM 
and Ops can be discussed separately, with LM covering provisioning, updates , and correction processes , 
and Ops focusing on monitoring, root cause analysis , and incident management.  
 
This chapter discusses the LM challenges SAP faces in operating a well-integrated suite that consists 
of our different business applications and services in a cost -effective manner  with consistent, fast, 
and consumer -grade SLAs . It describes a strategy that balances team -centric DevOps freedom and 
centralized reuse and u niformity (internally and for our customers). Thus, the strategy primarily 
addresses the needs of the role of an administrator of SAP applications and services and the 
customer roles enabling the consumption of these applications. The role of SAP admin may  be mixed 
with developer roles , depending on the operations model chosen. The needs of these roles need to 
be considered in the architecture of our applications and services, which is the focus of this topic 
area .  
Guidance Summary:  
• Expose LM aspects to the central customer services  (SAP for Me Customer Portal, 
CALM, SAP Support Portal) to better enable  the consumption of one integrated 
SAP. 
• Execute on TG04 to automate LM with  central and opinionated  LM services . 
• Applications /services  MUST  expos e a set of common metrics  (e.g., uptime  or traffic  
/ throughput ). 
• Applications /services  MUST target an  availability of 99.99% .

SAP’s North Star Architecture   
When talking about lifecycle management (LM), we need to talk about LM processes interfacing to 
each other along the lifecycle of the applications and services  (= end-to-end/E2E) and their not so 
obvious enterprise -grade features:  
The basic  E2E operations /lifecycle management 
processes (starting with  the phase “ Setup & Plan”)  define 
how  to visualize and plan landscapes and tool chains, 
handle application and service  dependencies, provison 
and update development artifacts and business content 
across landscape s, onboard and provision tenants, 
integrate these tenants  to each other , measure the  
application behavior and SLAs  conformity , find and solve 
incidents and problems, carry out routine tasks, scale and 
reconfigure the solutions  – and at some point in time 
decomission tenants and sunset  applications and 
landscapes. The most important proces ses are  
deployment (initial, update correction, feature 
management , integrated with build pipelines ), tenant 
provisioning, monitoring, root cause analysis, incident 
management, and landscape management .  
We identified the following main end-to-end features  needed for enterprise -grade operations : 
• For SAP cloud LOBs:  cloud reporting, access management to managed workloads, integration 
with SAP business systems (fulfillment, billing), corporate service desk integration, automation, 
operations compliance, metrics exposure for reporting and measurement  
• For SaaS customers : tenant availability, tenant landscape, notifications by SAP, service requests 
to SAP , one stop for all tickets  
The processes apply regardless of whether an application or service is managed in a DevOps, SRE  
(Site Reliability Engineering)  or traditional o perations model (DevOps = admins are the entire 
develop ment  team; SRE  = dedicated, but part -time admins; traditional = dedicated ops teams with 
no dev tasks). Today we find all these flavors at SAP.  
Product standards ( operatio ns and support, software life cycle) and Technology Guidelines already 
address LM aspects of our cloud native solutions. On the one hand, these solutions span hybrid 
landscapes including on -premise systems and, on the other hand, they consist of heterogeneous 
applications spanning mult iple technologies and a multitude of (micro)services. Therefore, there is 
still a lot to be done to reduce our TCO in view of this complexity and to support customer -facing 
uniformity, simplicity , and service availability as a natural consequence of the in tegration promise 
SAP made  to our customers. Our services do not always align on service level agreements or planned 
downtim windows, which lead to a degradation of experience. We also see inconsistency of metrics 
across cloud services with inconsistent fe edback loops. This inconsistency – coupled with monolithic 
architectures  – impede s flexibility to make choices and react to market conditions. Operationally, 
there is a large focus on custom environments driven by monolithic design and services that do  not 
expose cloud health/readiness endpoints. These services inconsistently report and log end -state 
information. Metrics across all areas are variable and the methods used to collect them are 
inconsistent with SLA  definitions for this service . Long mean times to restore  (MTTR)  and mean times 
to detection  (MTTD) , downtimes and high numbers of priority -1 incidents  are the consequence.  It is

SAP’s North Star Architecture  key to find the balance of the opposite poles of team -centric devops freedom and agility and 
centralized standards and  uniformity in order to achieve the two major goals : TCO reduction and 
centralized uniformity.  
Existing TGs: Automated Provisioning and Integration  
Streamlining the provisioning of tenants, the integration setup and monitoring, as well as the scoping 
of pr oducts as part of a central business configuration across all LoBs, are an important value 
proposition of the Intelligent Enterprise.  The ALM  cluster in the TGs  (cf. TG Whitepaper Cluster ALM ) 
presents a faster onboarding experience  including  significantly simplifi ed, automated  product 
integration and configuration . Ultimately, the described measures  therein reduce the time -to-value 
and implementation costs for our customers.  The cluster currently comprises three  guidelines :

SAP’s North Star Architecture   
Unified approach to lifecycle management, support, and operations consolidated across all LoBs:  
Customers want to operationally perceive SAP as one integrated application. Customer -centric 
operations and support,  as well as  application lifecycle managemen t should be a core concern, with 
a consolidated approach to  managing the entire lifecycle of applications and its key customer, 
employee, and stakeholder interactions  – for example,  automated provisioning of integrated 
solutions, reporting availability num bers to customers, a standardized way of reporting an audit -
relevant event, and shift -planning for DevOps and SRE. By reusing and harmonizing these 
operational and support concerns, we can provide a better customer experience – appearing as ONE 
SAP – and op timize our internal resources to focus on creating business value for our customers 
instead of reinventing the wheel for operations in every application.  Overall, we need to provide 
simple solutions th at are flexible enough to meet the needs of our diverse  applications and services 
and deliver value around lifecycle management w hile keeping adoption efforts low.  
(1) One integrated SAP from operations perspective  
Our customers want to perceive SAP as one integrated SAP also from an operations perspective. Th is 
means that customers want ONE confirmation after consistent provisioning of an Intelligent 
Enterprise solution. They also want to find ONE outage notification.  
• Customer perspective: One set of central services provides one façade for all customer -facing 
operations aspects across all applications in hybrid landscapes (e.g. , service request 
management, CALM (integration monitoring, testing)) . 
• Internal perspective : One set of  central services for the SAP LoBs implementing enterprise -grade 
features as standalone service s (e.g. , reporting, cloud access management, demand planning and 
forecast, automation infrastructure).  
(2) Managing heterogeneous/distributed applications   
Heterogeneous/distributed applications (using different technologies and  cloud services) are today’s 
and tomorrow’s reality. Managing these applications means operations of many different technical 
parts and landscapes as well as private clouds and partial deployments to the edge.  
These heterogeneous applications will be mana ged centrally. This is a great simplification compared 
to only managing their individual parts. For instance, it will be possible to deploy an application 
which is spread over multiple technologies and instantiated across the world with one single, 
central ly monitored operation.   
• These central services are , for example,  deployment, tenant provisioning, depiction of customer 
landscapes, downtime and activity management. Integration shall also comprise the enablement 
for automation and UI navigation.  They go beyond the existing scope of, for example, TG04 
(Automated provisioning and integration) or the System Landscape Information Kernel Service.  
• We integrate existing, siloed app/platform -specific operations tools to open central services. The 
integration hap pens via APIs and CLIs provided by these central services.  
• Hybrid applications with on -premise edge deployments (e.g. , the Kubernetes -based Industry 
4.Now  Edge) become increasingly important and therefore also deserve a standardized set of 
cloud -native LM services . 
• We need a go-to approach  to software lifecycle management  – for example,  how to deal with 
source code management, build and release pipelines to reach Continuous Deployment / 
Continuous Integration. Yet, there are  internally  competing approaches and tools  that need to be 
consolidated . This problem space needs further analysis in order to define  a clear way  forward .

SAP’s North Star Architecture  (3) Operational Excellence and TCO Reduction   
We want to get to a state where we can operate  our applications and services  with consistent, fast, 
consumer -grade SLAs around response time, throughput, and availability measured in absolute time, 
without maintenance, downtime, or acceptable failure window. The desired outcome is all about 
user experience and satisfaction, with r eduction in (MTTR) , (MTTD) , downtimes , and priority -1 
incidents.  
Beyond these basics, SAP needs to significantly reduce total cost of operations while not 
compromising on enterprise -grade operations. Standardization of cloud operations and meta data -
driven  integration of these standards avoid the development of costly application -specific operations 
tools/processes and speed up time to market.  
Thus , for an update, the application hands over its bill of material and the list of target landscapes to 
the stan dard provisioning service. The service schedules and executes the application components 
updates (software, content, configuration) across all target landscapes. The service ensures 
landscape consistency and legal compliance. With the integration  of this s ervice , the application 
benefits automatically from other E2E lifecycle management and enterprise -grade features like 
reporting and customer notifications services. Another example is monitoring: A n application picks 
the standard monitoring process templat e, adds its specific metrics to the automatically enabled 
standard metrics and then receives alerts – simple as that. The application components are 
automatically derived from the application ’s bill of material that was collected during the build and 
deplo yment of the application. In addition, the application automatically  benefits from the 
monitoring service’s intelligent, enterprise -grade features like data -lake-based event correlation and 
alert prediction or integration to reporting and customer notifica tions services.  
• We define and standardize a set of recommended (and thus opinionated), yet extensible LM 
processes/services providing basic processes AND enterprise -grade, intelligent features to 
applications (appropriate for used technology and infrastruc ture) including central services 
integration.  
• “Managed Build -on” applications are enabled out -of-the-box. 
• Improve process automation and SLAs by reduced runtime, automation, and avoidance of 
manual errors, optimizing (human) resource utilization backed by thoroughly measured 
application behavior .  
• Adopt  a culture of metrics by exposing – for each service – a baseline set of common metrics , 
such as  uptime, traffic/throughput, error rates, latency distribution (up to percentiles P 99 and 
P99.9) and saturation indicators (CPU, I/O, Memory, etc.), and by periodically reviewing these 
metrics through live dashboards.  
• Strive for an objective of 99.99% avai lability and require zero -downtime upgrades as well as 
99.99+% availability from the platform and infrastructure service providers.  
• Automation, automation, automation: applied to deployment, error resolution, or configuration 
tasks. It is noteworthy that a utomation also benefits from standardization. The more diverse the 
actors and sensors of the managed applications are, the more effort must be spent on providing 
dedicated automated procedures. Ideally, a production system should not require manual 
interve ntion (hands -off operational model) while ensuring no planned and (almost) no 
unplanned downtime.  
• Data collected during development, such as from automated test environments , also provides 
valuable insights for the continuous improvement.

Operational Hygiene: Metrics and SLAs  
The target state concerning  metrics  and SLAs  is an important outcome of the operational hygiene 
workstream of the PE CPA organization  (see Operational Hygiene Applied , limited access ) 
By standardizing the collected and shared  metrics, we increase our ability to share analysis as well as 
extend investigations across dependent services. To enabl e a harmonized view of the system health, 
we need the services to track and expose at least the following core metrics: availability/ uptime, 
traffic/throughput, error rates, latency distribution including tail behavior (P 99 and P99.9 percentiles), 
and saturation indicators (C PU, Memory, I/O. etc.).  
These simple metrics are all tied to customer expectations, as they show the reliability, speed , and 
consistency of the services . They apply to both internal customers and external customers, and they 
should be measured at every ext ernal and internal endpoint . 
Beyond threshold -based alert systems, live dashboards – with current state and trends – are used to 
proactively observe the service behavior and start corrective actions or optimization measures early. 
In addition, service revi ews with all involved stakeholders  should be scheduled on a regular basis  and 
the metrics  should be subsequently aggregated and reported up the product hierarchy.  
In terms of service level objectives, trying to achieve too high objectives will most likely 
overcomplicate the architecture, and thus  significantly increase the TCO, such that  the incremental 
cost of availability exceeds its value, while not necessarily affecting the vast majority of the user  
experience.  That  is why i t makes sense to categorize services into different tiers for setting 
expectations accordingly:  
• Treat  SaaS SLAs differently from PaaS/IaaS SLAs :  
Service owners have the responsibility to hold their dependencies accountable to SLA s that allow 
them to achieve their targets. This increases the pressure on and the expectations toward  the 
platform and infrastructure these services rely on. Therefore, the requirement for  zero -
downtime upgrades and “4 nines  plus” availability  fulfilled b y the infrastructure and platforms is 
essential . 
• Adopt a tiered approach ( 2-3 tiers) based on criticality of the  services : 
Differentiate business critical services (e.g. , identity) with very high SLA expectations from non -
interactive , non-critical backend services and every level in between . Set SLAs according to the 
criticality  and prioritize the effort.  
As we  are building and delivering the Intelligent Enterprise with end -to-end processes going across 
different products in the same call chain (e.g. , Concur to Success Factors), we must also consider the 
potentially very negative impact of integration on availability and performance . Weak  standards for 
individual application s and services add up o ver the call chain. For example,  the availability of a 10 -
call service chain with “4 nines” availaibility of each called service results in the call chain availability 
of only “3 nines”.  This is the reason  why  non-platform -level services involved in E2E pr ocesses must  
still meet  very high expectations . IES service providers  need to strive for availability/reliability levels  
of 99.99% .

Due to the inherent breadth and complexity of LM processes and topics, it is difficult to create the 
ultimate list of open  issues. An LM working group will soon be initiated. This group then shall jointly 
decide which topics deserve first attention. Therefore, consider the  following  list a s candidates to be 
tackled on the road to the target state:  
• One provisioning  (already underway as a cross project) : 
Automat ion of  tenant provisioning  for cross -appli cation parts of intelligent suite  E2E processes  
(by using and extending  TG04) 
• Harmonized ap proach to software lifecycle management : 
For example, how to deal with source code management, build and release pipelines to reach 
Continuous Deployment / Continuous Integration  
• Opinionated approach to Kubernetes operations : 
So far, there is no recommendation which services to use for which process  in the context of 
Kubernetes . It could comprise automated software provisioning  integrated with build and test 
pipelines , release management, feature management , but also monitoring  or logging .  
• (Human) Resource allocation and planning :  
SAP is not very good at planning ahead which “amount” of infrastructure and human resources 
we need t o provide and guarantee  our services. For example,  in the past we have ordered more 
hardware than was actually consumed .  
• Reduce planned downtime : 
While we strive to reduce planned  downtimes as much as possible, for the medium -term they  
are generally assumed to be here to stay. While the SaaS competitors also rely on  planned 
downtimes by excluding them from their SLAs, competing Iaas/PaaS service providers (with 
storage and compute services) generally have no concept of planned downtime. Integrations 
across SAP product areas and end -to-end intelligent suite  use cases are not possible , as long as  
each produ ct has its own planned downtime policy and window. It will probably take time  – and 
a lot of effort  – to get to a general zero -downtime upgrade situation across the board, and the 
price tag could be significant. However, assuming that SAP customers are OK with a common, 
planned, and limited downtime period every now and then, we must at least align all relevant  
product areas and services on a common planned downtime policy.

SAP’s North Star Architecture  End-to-end Extensibility   
This chapter discusses the end -to-end extensibility expe rience across the full intelligent suite 
portfolio, which plays a significant  role in the implementation experience of SAP customers. It  
explores the three  different perspectives on the extensibility experience:  
• Partner experience : Working with SAP , registering  as a partner , getting access to SAP solutions, 
registering and submitting partner applications for certification  by SAP, and getting insights into 
usage and interest from SAP customers . Last but not least , rolling out new versions and 
automatically managing integration with the intelligent suite . 
• Customer experience : Embedded in-app discovery , trial, enablement and decommissioning of  
partner -provided SAP solution extensions . Securely managing data access across the SAP 
portfolio of products , seamlessly  integrat ed into the  landscape of SAP and non -SAP products .  
• Developer experience:  Covering the full variety of technical and business service partners , which 
operate at global scale across different infrastructures, ranging from  add-on developers, who 
provide  specific modules to different products in our portfolio, all the way  to business process 
experts, who wish to customize and enhance the experience o f the SAP products, ideally on their 
own, without requiring development resources to be involved.  
• SAP product teams : SAP applications  to provide APIs for orchestration  of implementation -
related technical artifacts  and enable seamless , automated integration  of partner -provided  
extension scenarios across  the complete customer landscape . 
When discussing  extensibility , we consider the full sc ope of implementation projects  – starting from 
pure configuration  via domain model extensions  (using custom objects and custom fields ), enabling  
certified solution extensions, add -ons, and API consumption from SAP and non -SAP runtime 
environments  in side -by-side scenarios . We will establish KPIs for each of th ese aspects, to be used 
as indicators that we are moving in the right direction.  Finally , we explore  the role of SAP Graph as a 
consolidated entry point for building side-by-side extensions for SAP, as well a s process facilitation 
tools like CALM , SAP for Me, and SAP Partner Portal.  
 
 
Guidance Summary:  
• Applications  to provide  APIs to orchestrate all customizable product -specific aspects 
of an extension scenario  – custom fields  and objects , master data , code lists, security 
config uration , Events and API catalog , roles  and role assignments, workflows, 
business configuration , and integration  flows . 
• Provide  APIs, Events and a set of fine -grained data  access security scopes  via API for 
external consumption by  side-by-side scenarios.  
• Applications MUST  enforce security scopes on API -based  data access .  
• SAP Graph MUST  be adopted by applications → see Suite Quality  Central entry point 
for APIs and Events

Due to the structure of SAP’s cloud portfolio, formed out of many acquisitions and inhouse 
development, SAP’s customers  must  deal with many different customization and extensibility 
approaches . SAP’s products  are rarely  used straight out of the box, regardless of industry and region. 
There is always an implementation project, addressing the required customizations, reflecting the 
company -specific business processes and the required domain model  enhancements . Cloud service s 
and SaaS apps make no exception to this rule.   
A typical customer landscape contains multiple SAP and non -SAP solutions  – implemented over time 
by different teams  of experts  – covering the different  technologies . This involves a combination of 
product configurations, data model  customization  across multiple applications included in the 
respective business process, master data integration, and side -by-side extensions  that complement 
the buil t-in capabilities of the individual SAP solutions. When  strictly  followed, this approach  keeps  
application s free from custom  code (sometimes referred to as “back2standard”), while still providing 
rich-enough capabilities to influence and work with the data and the processes provided.   
To date , SAP still treats customers the way it treated them in former times, when on -prem ise 
systems were owned, installed , and managed by customer IT, leaving SAP with no direct access or 
control , depending on IT to provide details and ask for support. We handle cloud applications  in a 
very similar way, asking customers to grant access for support purposes , reproduce issues , and 
provide logs. When partner applications are to be integrated , customer IT is asked to generate 
credentials, configure URLs , and perform all the configurati on tasks required to pair the two 
solutions together. That  looks unnatural , given that it involves  SAP solutions, operated by SAP 
operations teams in SAP -controlled infrastructure. We can do better on the seamless integration 
automation front and get all of that burden away from our customer s’ hands  and eyes .  
The experience of partners is also very  scattered, depending on the solution they get involved with. 
A partner company  cannot reall y scale to the high -touch engagement model that SAP mandates for 
partner -provided extensions. There is no available automated integration/installation option , which 
partners can plug into, facilitating low -touch access to applications. Having one would allow them to 
scale to hundreds of SAP customers without the need  to hire hundreds of new consultants to 
perform installation activities.   
At the end , one-shot company -wide overhaul projects are scarce , and  different business processes 
are typically enabled i ncrementally over several years , each driving a new set of additional 
functionality and customizations.  SAP should  harmonize the customer and partner experience, when

SAP’s North Star Architecture  diving into implementation projects. It  is SAP’s responsibility  to define and implement a ll the 
integration pieces  that are  required to elevate all different product -specific customization to the 
level of the  intelligent suite,  to provide the highly anticipated #oneSAP experience. At the same time 
– to be successful – projects would also requi re an easy way to consume business data from the 
variety of SAP products, as well as securely and reliably run custom code without impacting the 
stability of the underlying SAP products. Having a large variety of cloud services, both SAP and 
partner -provid ed, will further complement the experience when customizing standard SAP processes  
and defining customer -specific ones.  
 
 
We must  radically reduce complexity and the learning curve for both developers and customers’ own 
IT to enhance and extend the experience of SAP products. Many of the successful partner 
applications we see growing today have started with this approach , typically in the context of a 
customer implementation project. At a later stage , they became more genera l and were turned into 
standalone products, addressing a particular SAP portfolio whitespace. One step to help people  is to  
provid e guidance and codified blueprints /templates  that serve as a starting point. Developers should 
use standard technologies and c oncepts and be able to get help using common information sources 
like Google, Stack Overflow , and active public communities.  
Key to developer engagement is the possibility to  use open source technologies , open protocols , and 
standard concepts. These are common knowledge outside of SAP . They slowly also penetrate SAP 
products with open source technologies becoming the norm . In many cases, selected open source 
projects/standards  will not be an exact match to what SAP needs – engaging and filling those g aps 
will impact SAP’s reputation  positively  and ensure strategic investments are made where they can 
make a difference  for the wider developer ecosystem out there .  
While it may be necessary at times to create SAP proprietary development frameworks, deviat ing 
from mainstream  common knowledge  leads to higher cost and lower adoption in the long run .

SAP’s North Star Architecture  Partner Ecosystem  
SAP’s partners play , will  play, and alw ays have played a key role in our success. They serve as 
multipliers of our internal knowledge, our technology, and our customer reach. At the same time, 
they take over a substantial amount of integration, adaptation, extension, and customization effort, 
that – without partners – we would never be able to manage in reasonable time . It is therefore in 
SAP’s own interest to strengthen and empower its partner ecosystem wherever possible . 
While a n SAP developer has access to internal knowledge resources, source  code, and development 
teams in case of questions or problems, partners do not. They depend  on proper documentation, 
stable software, and their prior knowledge of existing cloud technologies and common engineering 
patterns. Therefore, w e need to simplify o ur technology stack by using common industry  tools and 
frameworks ourselves.  
It is not a question whether SAP’s intelligent suite shall be extensible  – there is no other way . Our 
extension points enable partners to contribute to our ecosystem, to fill the white spots, and thrive in 
their domain . Delivering on this vision strengthen s the long -term commitment to our core products 
and make s SAP even more attractive, enabling commerci al partner opportunities.  
To enable partners to be successful , SAP must change how partners are supported and how they  are 
enabled to participate efficiently as part of SAP's ecosystem. To attract a larger set of partners , SAP 
must  improve the process how  application integration is certified, how solutions are positioned , and 
how they are made available to third  parties . Among others, this will include the following steps :  
• Access to Kernel Services  for certified partner applications and services. Partner applications 
must integrate almost  natively with  the rest of the SAP portfolio of products to provide a 
coherent and integrated experience. This includes all functionality offered by Kernel Services to 
the rest of the SAP portfolio.  
• A security review process which provides, in a timely manner, an assessment of whether a 
partner application is “safe” to be entrusted with access to our customer s’ data  or not . It serves 
as a gate to make sure that no misuse of customer data takes place b y rogue partner 
applications. Once certified , partner application provisioning/integration is to be managed by 
SAP to ensure that what is provided to  customers is the same as what has been certified.  
• Expose Business Events programmatically  – allowing admi nistrators and developers to manage 
events  centrally, via API and application UIs. Events are  remotely consum ed by side -by-side 
extension apps  on SAP and non -SAP platform s.  
• Provide API s to enable external orchestration of predefined business process workflows for the 
injection of custom external steps. Offering pre - and post -step hooks is also a good practice, 
allowing the customization of the workflow behavior.  
Extensions should look and feel like SAP products concerning UX, audit logs, data access control, 
authentication, authorization, additional customizations, navigation, search, API exposure , and 
consumption channels (desktop, mobile, voice, API). Partner -provided extensions should not 
negatively impact the compliance and certificati on state of the customer landscape (PCI, FedRamp, 
HIPPAA, etc.). Kernel Services  are key to achieving this . A pivot point to enable self -service in-app 
low-touch discovery and consumption of certified functionality published via SAP AppCenter , will 
lower the bar further for partners to become part of the SAP ecosystem and deliver additional value 
to our mutual  customers.

SAP’s North Star Architecture  Required SAP Product Enhancements  
We treat software extensibility as an essential integration quality  for SAP products , in order  to make 
extensions  part of the unified intelligent suite  #oneSAP experience.  Going forward, we must provide 
the glue to tie  products and extension scenarios together , adding to the experience , regard less of 
the infrastructure and runtime they run on.  
To achieve this, SAP products must expose internal orchestration APIs, allowing central  management 
of all customizable artifacts , including , but not limited to:  
• Hierarchical security scopes  to be present ed to IT admins and security experts when reviewing 
the data access requirements of partner scenarios . 
• User profiles and respective role  assignment  MUST be programmatically  manageable.  
• API clients  and secrets  to en able data access , limited  to the certified set of scope s defined 
above . 
• UI customization  enabling the enhancement of standard screens and navigation flows . 
• Theming , branding , and navigation , allowing partner extension scenarios  to integrate with the 
customer -specific customized look and feel in a coherent manner and present experience, 
consistent with the rest of the involved products . 
• Custom business objects and custom fields  will allow partner scenarios to enhance the standard 
SAP-defined domain model and enhance it to reflect the needs of the respective industry or 
customer domain . 
• Business process and integration workflow  management  will enable the insertion of custom 
steps, involve external systems , generate events , and provide the level of flexibility  expected by

programmatically . 
A Central Management Plane service (CMP) will use these APIs for orchestrating the pairing  across 
the various systems  in the customers’ IT landscape, included in the partner -defined  extension 
solution . 
When writing about APIs , we can not omit the crucial as pect of data protection. Customer data is of 
utmost importance to SAP  and it is our duty to ensure that data access is tightly controlled. We must  
ensure that no partner application has wildcard data access but is scoped down to the particular  
scenario it certified , and which was explicitly approved by a customer IT administrator  to be enabled.  
Data access must be  adequately logged, consistently following the individual compliance 
requirements for the respective industry (i.e., HIPPAA, FedRamp, PCI, etc.).  
Side -by-side Extensibility  
The side -by-side model is heavily inspired by the extensibility approaches originally pioneered in the 
business -to-consumer (B2C) cloud world. Likewise, the model embraced by SAP Cloud Platform 
Extension Factory is based on a set of stable APIs and Events exposed by the connected enterprise 
application s (e.g., SAP Commerce Cloud or SAP Marketing Cloud). These are used to trigger 
extension logic or to leverage  native functionality of the application, such as the one creating or 
reading an order in a commerce application.  
By leveraging this approach, various problems that are generally associated with building and 
running ex tensions can be mitigated. One of the most common issues with extensions and 
©2020 SAP SE – Internal    77 
  
 
SAP’s North Star Architecture  customizations is a failure during upgrades of the SaaS application, often caused by undeclared 
dependencies on changed parts of the system. IT departments are frequently asked to  make trade -
off decisions between following the business need and being future  proof. By effectively decoupling 
custom -provided from SAP code through a stable API contract, this issue is largely mitigated.  
Another frequent business demand is agility and th e opportunity to try out new concepts and 
approaches. This is often countered by the risk of unintentionally breaking the main application with 
changes (causing regressions). The general strategy established to mitigate this is to accumulate 
multiple chang es, package them in a release, test whether changes work as intended (integration -
acceptance -test), test whether the existing functionalities or processes in the system still work 
(regression  test), and then move on to production. This approach is time -consuming and anything 
but agile. With the side -by-side model, every extension has its own independent lifecycle, so 
extensions and customizations can move to production independently much more quickly without 
running the risk of breaking the (unchanged) core  application. After all, the famous advice to “never 
change a running system” is still true.  
The problem of consistency in customizations across applications is another issue the side -by-side 
extensibility approach can improve. In an omnichannel world, con sistency across touchpoints and 
channels is critical. Ensuring this across different software implementations or products is hard, 
primarily when they are implemented one by one in the various products themselves. However, 
providing the application in a ce ntralized, preconnected platform is a significant advantage when it 
comes to consistency and cost efficiency (implement once, use everywhere).  
Software is moving away from the model of delivering a few large, monolithic applications to 
delivering many diff erent microservices. To realize the benefits of microservices, technology choices 
are made at a much lower level. This implies operating in a fragmented landscape of heterogeneous 
database technologies, programming languages, and frameworks. Instead of abs orbing all these 
different technologies, side -by-side extensibility defines an abstraction of these implementation 
details (through the stable contract) and gives the extension developer a choice.  
In-App Extensibility  
Side -by-side extensions come with many advantages, the primary one being the resulting native user 
experience . However, they are not the one -size-fits-all solution for all customizations. To implement 
an end -to-end process, multiple building blocks must be put in place. Th is includes all required 
changes, starting with customizing applications’ configuration and o bject model to developing new 
side-by-side extension applications  to consume them . At a high level, in -app extensions should help 
to empower business user s to adapt the ir working environment, without the need for development 
resources, whereas side -by-side extensions give developers full control and options to develop and 
support new business application use cases.  
Configuration tasks, such as setting the preferred language or other simple configurations for the 
individual user, should be the easiest to per form and are under control of the end user. Operational 
reporting enables end users to derive insights from their data in the application itself flexibly. UI 
configurations provide users comfort in the ir environment and increase productivity. All these 
options must be intuitive in terms of usability, but because they are predefined, there is no real 
flexibility. As preset options that are part of the main application, they should be handled in -app.  
Workflow tools help to automate and formalize processes wi thin and across applications. Data 
model enhancements are  used  to customize the application’s existing business objects with 
additional fields and to expose them via the application’s API. Custom rules help to implement all 
sorts of functionality ranging f rom validations to pricing logic and promotion rules —yet they are not 
as powerful as programming. Customized UIs can enrich the application with functionality from

SAP Graph  
While all the Suite Qualities are important, we focus here on one central quality, 
the Aligned Domain Model  (DMA initiative ). The idea is very simple to explain: a 
single, consistent representation of business objects across all SAP applications that 
form the intellige nt suite, that can be easily accessed via a single unified API .  
Existing SAP applications, naturally grown or acquired by SAP, come with a plethora 
of legacy APIs, data representations , and domain models. The challenge of forging 
these into a single unified domain model and API is considerable, bearing in mind 
the thousands of applications that already use these. Instead, SAP is committed to 
deliver a new, modern side -by-side API, that e xposes a unified domain model that is compatible with  
the existing applications.  
We refer to this API by the name of SAP Graph (cf. TG39 – SAP 
Graph ). Like an y other API, The SAP Graph API is a contract  
between SAP and its clients (the customer and partner client 
applications).  
SAP Graph is an API for accessing SAP-managed data. It 
exposes a unified  graph -like domain model  of business objects 
(entities) and re lationships (hence its name). App lication  
developers use SAP Graph as a RESTful service to navigate and 
access the data, regardless of where (in which business system) 
this data resides, using open standards such as OData v.4  or 
GraphQL.  
SAP Graph  will hug ely simplify the challenge for partners and 
make their effort largely reusable across different customer

SAP-wide API Gateway  
One missing piece at the core of our platform is an SAP -wide API Gateway. Such an SAP -wide API 
Gateway would enhance observability, and could be used for metering, authentication , and 
consumption throttling, with connections to the individual products and product areas. It would also 
help hide the complexity of our varied landscapes, geographies, and authentication schemes based 
on industry standards such as OAuth  or JWTs.  
An SAP -wide API Gateway could become a simple and effective way to unify authentication, 
observability, security controls, and metering and monetization through APIs. The API Gateway must 
scale to support the combined traffic of all SAP applications with sufficien t ingress/egress bandwidth, 
automated/self -service processes for change management, and manage the lifecycle of the APIs. A 
tall requirement.  
Such an API Gateway can also be the foundation of SAP Graph and its growing ecosystems of internal 
and external adoptions with partners.

SAP’s North Star Architecture  Security and Identity Management  
The intelligent suite can have the best technology and provide the most innovative solutions that 
support the digital transformation our customers are looking for  – without the core missio n of cyber 
security, not much of this will matter. This chapter is dedicated to identity management and other 
North Star Architecture  security topics.  It highlights how we SHALL build  up a n SAP -wide  
homogenous  security infrastructure to improve interoperab ility as well as customer satisfaction.  
 
Guidance Summary:  
• Security -related Kernel Service  (e.g. for Identity, Audit Log) MUST be adopted   
• Use authorization claims, instead of identities, for access control decisions. 
Authorization claims are passed from the central authorization service to the 
applications using OAuth2 and JWT tokens . 
• Customers need a single place to control security aspects of their landscape. This 
mandates central policy definition and local execution, leveraging platform -native 
features (e.g. , for encryption) . Open Standards enable this approach . 
• Use cryptography and explicitly  described  target states  (infrastructure as code)  to 
make sure environments are auditable and checks can be automated .

SAP applicati ons are often  the crown  jewels of our customer s’ system landscape s. Our  customers 
have high expectations about the platform harmonization of  security, data protection , legal and 
regulatory compliance , and integration . SAP’s evolutionary approach towards cloud computing and 
our acquisitions have compounded our challenges . 
As referenced in this document’s section  “SAP’s Business Technology Platform ”, our focus is on 
integration and harmonizatio n across the intelligent enterprise . Work towards this goal has already 
started, as evident by  the afore mentioned TGs and Kernel Services : 
• Centralization of Identity and Access Management  for end users  
• Central collection of Security -Audit -relevant data  (logs)  
• Data Privacy  and Encryption  across applications  (Central K ey Management and others)  
A critical element in building a strong foundation for harmonization and integration is the ad option 
of the customer managed “Zones” concept. Zones  help to apply the same security context and 
policies to group s of related SAP application s and platform s throughout the customer ’s landscape.

SAP’s North Star Architecture   
Security is a cross -cutting concern . Most customers have central departments that mandate a certain 
set of com plianc e checks. One of the key drivers for SAP Security is to simplify this  through a n SAP -
wide  Security Management Control Plane , as indicated by the Security Cross -Concern at the right 
side of Figure 6 (Page 24). The control plane enables  customers  to centrally define and observe 
security -relevant policies  and events . Although control is exerted  centrally, execution of rules and 
data collection stays local  to the distributed and self -contained runtime environments .  
This is enabled by  open standards like OAuth2, flexible and accepted open source concepts like Rego 
(Open Policy  Agent ) and others  to connect  execution environment s and control plane . Figure 19 
shows the high -level relationship between control plane and  execution  environments.  By default,  
policies are taken in  and audit relevant events  are sent  out for display, evaluation , and analys is.  
 
Figure 19: Security Control Plane  
To increase efficiency and decrease time to market , the architecture strategy is to leverage native 
platform  services (including those of hyperscalers)  for execution and data collection. Using open 
standards for integration of these services  will mitigate the risk of lock -in. 
Identity, Access & Authorization  
Often considered the perimeter for defense in the clou d, Identity , Access , and Authorization  adds 
strongly governed authorization handling to  end user  identity management , expanded to 
administrators  and machines ( systems /tenants/applications) . In such a setup, machines can act as 
themselves (e.g. , the e -commerce system calls  the pricing engine  for a basket calculation) or on 
behalf of an end  user or administrator ( e.g., a user approves  a travel expense in the universal inbox).  
To shield applica tions and platforms from the complexity of this model , services/applications SHALL  
in the future base all access control decisions on authorizations rather than on caller identity. This is 
achieved by a service acting as a central OAuth2 -compliant authorization server. The service will 
identify and authenticate the caller and will then issue short -lived Json Web Token ( JWT ) style  

©2020 SAP SE – Internal    82 
  
 
SAP’s North Star Architecture  authorization tokens  to be presented to the target a pplication . By default, the receiving applications 
SHALL apply  offline validation to check integrity and trust . Tokens will be issued to users ( end users, 
administrators) and machines (for machine -to-machine communication and “on -behalf” access).  
Following this approach SAP will:  
• Enable custom ers to centrally manage  permissions  in a distributed system / landscape , 
• Move complexity out of applications , 
• Simplify service consumption for the service ecosystem as well as custom developments . 
The authorization grants managed by this service SHALL be b ased on a central role management 
system. However , the services as such will not interact with this service directly.

Certain crypto aspects can be applied 
universally across all platforms, like the 
definition of allowed algorithms, 
standards for encryption at rest, etc.  
The majority of this is not the 
responsibility of the North Star 
Architecture , but rather the policies  and 
guidelines that are generated by the work 
of the architecture team and SGS teams. 
That  said, a few strategic initiatives will 
be introduced : 
• Kernel Service  Central  Key 
Management  
• Universal  platform  encryption  for data at rest   
• Universal encryption of data in transit  
To enable  the principle of centralized contro l, encryption keys can be  centrally managed in a data 
custodian  and leveraged by the respective infrastructures and services.  
A centrally managed SAP -wide certificate authority will be used to meet the strong identification and 
authentication mechanisms en forced within the intelligent suite. LoBs will establish subordinate 
certificate authorities to be used for Mutual TLS ( mTLS ) by the service mesh plane and with system -
to-system communication over service APIs. As one example, this will be used to establish the trust 
between an entity and the authorization server for the purpose of issuing authorization tokens used 
by this entit y for accessing other services and applications.  
Beyond establishing system trust in communication, the established certificate infrastructure will 
also serve as a foundation for securing software delivery through cryptographically signed 
dependencies and code execution with signed images and binaries.  
Policies and Compliance  
Legal and regulatory c ompliance is an important concern for SAP and our customers. However , 
compliance requirements differ from industry to industry, country to county , and from organi zation 
to organization. What is unanimous though , is that compliance does not stop at SAP application 
boundaries. To cater to these facts, the central security control plane will provide the means to 
express requirements in the form of policies that are then distributed to the respective applications 
and platforms. These will be responsible for executing the centrally defined , declarative policies.

Relevant SAP Kernel Services and TGs, like  TG34 - Data Privacy Integration, will integrate into the

Audit, Access Logs & SIEM  
The audit log Kernel S ervice  enables  compliance to meet  the applicable industry and regulatory 
obligations  from a  single, end -to-end, consistent view of the aud it trail.   
 Applications MUST use this facility to capture audit -relevant events, as defined by SAP product 
standards, to allow correlation across systems and applications.  
All platform runtimes SHALL  be, by default , instrumented with clients forwarding the audit logs in a 
secure and reliable manner. The application will need to make additional effort only in two cases:  
1. When using the "Integrate -with" runtime option, the application should use a client from the 
list o f supported clients and non-proprietary protocols  (e.g. , rsyslog, fluentd) and configure it 
according to the instructions of the audit log service . 
2. When the application requires synchronous (blocking) logging, it should use the API exposed 
by the audit log service . 
Security Information and Event Management (SIEM , see also Open Issues below ) is a software 
solution that aggregates and analyzes activity across the entire IT infrastructure. The audit log 
service is responsible for enforcing the policie s applicable to the given customer.  This may involve 
sending the logs to the existing SIEM solution employed by the customer or storing the logs in a trail 
served by the underlying hyperscaler.  
Secure Perimeter  
Building and running modern , distributed , and internet -facing  applications on multiple 
infrastructures requires strict control over code and configuration. A secure software delivery 
lifecycle and pipeline  helps to standardize an d automate this.  As cloud infrastructures  become 
harder and harder to br each, attackers are moving their focus to the developer , poisoning libraries 
and injecting harmful code into the boundary. Applying the principles of cyber security to the entire 
software development and deployment process is a critical element which is of ten overlooked. SAP 
developers  must be provided with two important aspects of assurance : the platform is ‘secure by 
default’, and their code has been validated as approved before, during, and after being deployed.  
This MUST  be achieved with strict dependency management  (libraries and base images) , signing , and 
automated checks at build time.  
Configuration SHALL be  constantly validated against global policies  (dealing with, e.g., missing 
encryption, invalid access rights, und esired network exposure , etc .) and a desired state ( e.g., no 
potential malicious activities) . Automation of compliance happens in three places: before, during and 
after.  
• Before: Scanning of infrastructure code must be available before code is pushed. Valid ation 
should warn developers that there could be a possible issue, before they attempt to integrate 
their code.  
• During: Infrastructure code must be scanned during deployment. As our capabilities mature, 
we can progress from generating simple warnings to bl

SAP’s North Star Architecture  User Experience  
The North Star goal  for UI/UX , following the design philosophy of SAP Fiori, is to create a “Consi stent 
and Modern Fiori User Experience for the Intelligent Enterprise”  on mobile, browser , and desktop . 
Different UIs from different applications integrate seamlessly , based on micro frontend components. 
Frontend developers benefit from a superior develope r experience, based on choice, modularity , 
and inner source.  We value consistency, stability , and productivity over adopting latest technology.  
To deliver features for the Intelligent Enterprise on a large scale we must  overcome product borders 
and reuse domain -specific frontends, so that they can be assembled into a higher -level aggregated 
product. We believe decoupling monolithic frontends  into reusable mi cro frontends  (belonging to  
microservices ) will enable teams to own a feature end to end. This will enable us to provide features 
in an agile manner, reducing duplicated development efforts across LoBs, allowing independent and 
secure releases of micro fro ntends.  
 
Guidance Summary:  
• Mandatory adoption of Fiori Design guideline  
• Adoption of shared UI services for One Inbox, Product Switch, Conversational AI  
• Adopt ion of  micro  frontend patterns to prepare composability  
• Implement ation of  client -side analytics across apps

SAP introduced  Fiori Design Principles in 2013 to modernize the SAP user experience. The SAP Fiori 
Design philosophy is based on five core principles: role -based, adaptive, simple, coherent , and 
delightful. With the UX Consistency Product Standard  the groundwork is laid to ensure consistency.  
So far, SAPUI5  is the best -practice reference implementation of the Fiori Design Language. Yet, a first 
step towards opening up the S AP frontend was taken by the Fundamental Library Styles , which 
provides a Fiori -3-based CSS layer for frequently used components. This CSS layer can be integrated 
with any web framework. In addit ion, there are implementations for popular open  source UI 
frameworks, such as Angular , React , or Vue. With the browser support  of the Web Component  
standards, we see an evolution of browser and web technology for writing reuse UI components. 

©2020 SAP SE – Internal    86 
  
 
SAP’s North Star Architecture  Following these groundbreaking changes in UI web development, UI5 Web Components  provide a 
comprehensiv e set of Web Components which are conform ant to the Fiori Design guidelines17. 
On an ABAP stack most  SAP customers are still using classic UI technologies like Web  Dynpro and 
SAPGUI. These technologies recently adopted Fiori -3 designs resulting in  a Fiori -like look -and-feel for 
several 1000 applications . In addition , several SAP cloud products come with their own UI 
framework.  
These multiple UI technologies require a profound and harmonized UI stack, providing all necessary 
assets to enable developers writ ing micro frontends which are conform to product standards.  
 
 
This section provide s a starting point for a future looking guidance  targeting 2025  and an upcoming 
Nort h Star workstream . 
Fiori User Experience  
From an end user perspective, t he Fiori User Experience  is the overarching goal. End users demand a 
modern, fast, consistent , and appealing user experience with features that help them getting their 
jobs done faster. As such , the Fiori Design MUST be adopted. Bringing SAP products together in one 
harmonized user experience not only requires to follow the TG10 Consistent User Experience  and UX 
Cons istency Product Standard  for colors, iconography, typography, etc. but also integrating all 
products seamlessly, using a common approach to UI -based integration. Having a consistent look 
and feel across the different SAP applications, but across partner -provided extension solutions as 
well, is key to getting closer to #oneSAP experience for customers.  
Browser Support  
The proposed UI stack should run on all devices ( desktop, tablet, mobile), in all latest (evergreen), 
major browsers, which support  Web Components , at least : 
• Chrome: >= version 69  
• Microsoft Edge: >= version 79 (based on Chromium)  
• Firefox: >= version 63  
• Safari >= version 11  
To adopt new browser features shortly after release, we should support the latest  browser version . 
This should also apply when embedding web views in desktop or m obile applications. When  a 
browser does  not support a new productivity feature, we should use techni ques like transpiling, 
polyfills , and allow graceful degradation.  
Mobile Support  
SAP products must run on mobile devices. For mobile browsers the UI stack m ust support responsive 
designs and building  Progressive Web Application  (PWA). Offline first and notification features 
should be integrated into the UI stack , and the UI SDK needs to provide good examples how to build 
state -of-the-art PWAs.  
Depending on the use case, an application might be implemented as native mobile application. 
Native application development must be reduced to a bare minimum – only apps that are consumer -
