Theming  
Customers must be able to easily replace the logo and the branding color as well as other colors in 
the user interface to adapt our UIs to their needs. It is important that customers have an aligned 
approac h and a central access point to theme the different SAP products they use. To allow these 
theming capabilities (UXC -011) across UI5 and non -UI5 based frameworks, all Cascading Stylesheets 
(CSS) must be based on the  Cross Technology Theme Parameters . Their consumption will allow to 
integrate with the UI Theme Designer, which allows the customization of a theme by an admin user 
in a WYSIWYG fashion.  
UI Integration and Micro Frontends  
SAP has promised to deliver end -to-end processes and a #oneSAP experience when moving from one 
product to another. Therefore, we need to provide an easy to u se architecture for UI integration for 
all kind s of products, applications and assets , independent of UI technologies. It must be easy to 
integrate with existing application content into an arbitrary representation (e.g. , simple Web Page, 
classic UIs).   
We need Central Entry Points as described in TG14 . These entry points render components and 
entire single page applications  inside .  
 To seamlessly integrate into the central entry point, as minimal viable scope every application 
MUST provide a manifest.json based on the Common Data Model (CDM) and MUST 
implement TG01 for cross product navigation.  
Applications will be buil t based on micro frontends and reusable building blocks.  Micro  frontends are 
defined as : "An architectural style where independently deliverable frontend applications are 
composed into a greater whole" . A central micro frontend framework allows to create loosely 
coupled and modular applications. It provides and opinionated way for communication and 
navigation between micro frontends. Fiori floorplans would contain micro frontend containe rs and 
the central micro frontend framework would take care of placing the right micro frontend into these 
containers. This approach allows even nesting of micro frontends or opening them in dialogs or 
overlays , i.e. micro  frontends are not restricted to s imple floor plans or big building blocks . Micro 
frontends can be provided and integrated by the host application in two different flavors:  
• Web Component  – The micro frontend is provided as a Web Component. The integration 
scenario owner trusts the micro frontend and can directly integrate the Web Component . 
• iFrame  – The micro frontend is provided via a URL (e.g. , for server side rendered micro 
frontends, cl assic UI technologies , or third -party content) and is isolated integrated via an 
iframe. In another possible scenario the micro frontend is provided as a Web Component, but 
the integration scenario owner does not trust  the micro frontend.  
An example for a n SAP -developed  approach  in this space is the Luigi  micro frontend framework , that  
provides a state -of-the-art micro frontend architecture and is used in SAP CX products. As an open 
source library, one of the si gnificant advantages of Luigi is, that it can be used standalone, without 
dependencies to a central service. In case a Luigi -based application runs standalone (without a 
central entry point), it provides a shell bar and side navigation, so that teams do no t have to 
reimplement such central UI elements and floorplans.

SAP’s North Star Architecture   Reusable building blocks should be built as Web Components and can come with a central 
SAP service attached – for example, product switch , search , inbox , user settings , home 
pages , web assistant , or conversational AI .  
Once these reusable components become available, they MUST be adopted to provide the 
relevant cross -product functionality in the entire intelligent suite . 
 
Figure 21: Integration Scenario with Micro Frontends  
Furthermore,  we envi sion domain -specific reusable building blocks  around “Material”, “Customer”, 
“Contract”, “Workforce Person”, “Sales Order Processing”, etc. These could be composable  and 
reusable  views for listing, editing , searching, finding , or otherwise interacti ng with domain objects. 
All these Web Components can be placed anywhere on a web page and work without or with only 
little configuration. This will allow teams to release building blocks independently and foster reuse 
and modularization across teams.  
Application s SHALL therefore provide UI building block s and micro frontend s for their domain. These 
will be based on central and common Web Components that implement  the latest Fiori designs and 
behaviors, like UI5 Web Components.  
Harmonizing the UI stack based on Web Components reduce s the specific UI framewor k footprint 
and allow s reus ing and collaborat ing around UI components  in the heterogeneous UI framework 
environment  independently o f using SAPUI5, Angular, React , or Vue.  
UI Develop er Experience  
A key to success for acceptance and adoption of the new UI stack is a seamless and delightful 
development experience for our developers. Developers should  not need to care about the best way 
to create a micro frontend or how and where to deploy it. Therefore, it is crucial that we provide 
great tool support for th e proposed UI technologies, so that our developers can create new micro 
frontends in a fast and efficient way. This experience should support the whole development process  
– from starting a new micro frontend from scratch, continue with assistance during t he 
development , and provide a one -click testing and deployment of the software . The approach  also 
ensures the ability to evolve  to the latest versions and guidance with automated migration bots.  For 
this purpose, the proposed Developer Experience portal ca pabilities should also cover these UI -
related aspects.

SAP’s North Star Architecture  Web UI SDK and Web UI Component Development Kit (CDK)  
 
 
Figure 22: Definition of UI Building Blocks  
To enable SAP developers, customers , and partners to develop solutions in a standardized and fast 
way, we must provide a UI SDK for web development. This SDK should contain all necessary UI 
building blocks, connectors to our central services, configuration, IDE integrations , and tooling to 
create applications or reus able micro frontends  out of the box. It  contain s the common Web 
Component layer based on UI5 Web Components . Built on top of these , richer Web Components and 
micro frontends are offered. When using such a building block  we need to provision the 
corresponding service directly  if applicable.  Applications  can be built as micro frontend s, as 
explained in “ UI Integration and Micro Frontends ”, with any application UI framework  and the 
aligned micro frontend library that can evolve out of Luigi .  
To create Web Components in a standardized way , we need a UI Component Development Kit (CDK). 
This CDK contains assets to theme components based on Fiori designs, like the Cross Technology 
Theme Parameters  and shared styles and layouts  evolving out of Fundamental Library Styles  and the 
existing SAPUI5 controls . Common logic like date handling, i18n, dialog handling, and event -
drive n/reactive backend connectivity will be available as independent modules  that can be loaded 
only when required.  This might be the modular UI5 core as depicted in the UI5 evolution roadmap.

SAP’s North Star Architecture   
Metadata -Drive n UI 
Many of our UIs consist of simple list & details views, showing a list of available objects as a table 
and the details representation of it. Instead of writing such domain -object -specific UIs for common 
CRUD operations (Create, Read, Upd ate, Delete) manually again and again, developers should be 
able to generate such generic UIs based on a meta model.  
Part of the UI SDK and CDK will be the option to have metadata -driven (smart) UI component s. As 
Web Components , these metadata driven UIs c an be embedded in any floorplan.  
Low -code  / No-code  for UIs  
Casual developers (aka  “citizen developers ”) need to be empowered to create simple UIs 
themselves. With the help of rich reuse building blocks , metadata -driven UIs from the UI SDK , and 
visual editors , citizen developers could easily create full applications or micro frontends. Visual 
editors allow to add  small bits of glue code and configuration of reuse components. The micro 
frontend framework used internally will allow modelling a nd navigation through entire  processes. By 
creating the projects based on the developer portal, also features like build pipelines and 
repositories will be set  up directly , allowing to deploy on different targets – for example,  cloud or 
mobile app stores.  
UI Extensibility and Adaptation  
The new UI stack will also enable the extension and adaption of our UIs in an easy and fast way, 
requiring no to little programming knowledge : end users can personalize their  UI – for example,  by 
adding a column  or a filter to a table . Key users can adjust  or configure  UIs visually  for the whole 
company . Extension fields can be added to the UI as described in the extensibility chapter . Partner s,

SAP’s North Star Architecture  customer s, and SAP developer s can add elements to the UIs via declarative  UI change s. All changes 
should be stored in a central service (like personalization or key user service) and allow layering of 
these changes.  
User  Behavior Tracking (Web Analytics)  
Knowing how user s interact with  our UIs will give us important insi ghts  to help us improve our UIs 
continuously . For example:  
• Which path does a user normally take through our products to fulfill certain tasks? Do we 
need to optimize the screens?  
• What is the real performance a user receives?  
• Is something crashing internall y? In a cloud environment we need to be able to recognize 
errors in our micro frontends in real time.  
 Therefore, for all major interactions an event MUST be raised within the client and be 
available for a client -side tracking component to consume. All errors MUST be available for a 
client -side tracking component to consume. All data MUST always be collected 
anonymously, i.e. events MAY NOT contain personal data. The user  MUST have the 
possibility to opt -in and opt -out to allow us to collect  the data, for which standard UI 
building blocks must be used.  
We should always deploy new features behind a feature toggle. This will allow us to speed up 
development and get feedback from a certain user group  (e.g. , for A/B Testing). Another advantage 
is to disable a live feature when an error occurs.  
Modularity  and Inner Source  
We already see the benefits of inner  and open  source at SAP: Instead of creating features locally, 
more and more teams provide features centrally for everyone. We need to create such a community 
around the whole UI stack with shared ownership across all products and central groups. Everyone 
should be invited to contribute equally entitled new features or bugfixes in the shared reuse 
components from UI CDK over the UI SDK to domain -specific reuse micro frontends. Therefore, we 
must provide an inner source process with agreed guidance and governance which  should be 
supported by tools (e.g. , linting, UX consistency testing).  
An inner source approach will also remove  the overload of ce ntral teams and allows to add value to 
the products instantly without waiting for another team to build it. This culture change will increase  
trust and knowledge exchange between  teams and will help individuals to contribute to the success 
of each of our p roducts.  Having a central starting point to reach  all these publicly available  
repositories, issue tracker s, and roadmap s will support the inner source process  so that  one can 
easily find where to contribute . 
 
 
Upcoming technologies like augmented and virtual reality are not yet part of this strategy. We need 
to invest igate  how to reuse as much as possible , once these technologies take over the browser 
market.  
With concepts like draft handling and avoiding redundant requests, we have to in vestigate how to 
share frontend state across technologies in the client. This would also help to implement consistent 
undo/redo behavior.  

©2020 SAP SE – Internal    92 
  
 
SAP’s North Star Architecture  In the mobile space, frameworks like React Native, Google Flutter , and Native Script come up to ease 
native mobile dev elopment. We need to investigate if we should give guidance here and if so, which 
framework to propose. Maybe some of the web art ifacts could be reusable in one or the other cross -
platform  framework.  
In a microservice architecture world, data that is requi red by the micro frontends to render the UI, 
must most times be collected from different services  and merged in the client. This approach has the 
disadvantage of having many requests, which might block the subsequent request, resulting in a bad 
performance . One approach to solve this performance problem, is to write specific services for a UI, 
which aggregate  the data on the backend and send s them to the client in one request (backend for 
frontend). While the performance is improved by this  solution, the do wnside is a huge amount of UI -
specific services. Instead of having individual services for each micro fronted, we should investigate 
using an abstraction layer (maybe GraphQL) for accessing the data of the microservices in a reactive 
and event -driven way.  
Server -side rendering can provide significant performance improvements for the initial load. 
However , getting the lifecycle and updates of all the multiple components aligned to serve up to 
date content is hard and needs to be investigated further.  
A devel oper portal will help cloud and citizen developers to kickstart their development . The Eureka  
project and T&I developer experience are working on a developer portal, which could provide a 
starting place also for UI developers.
